Bg8qcBBBzN8jvMAd68zr-g.text: Came here to try out their pho. Also ordered an Vietnamese iced coffee to pair off with the food. The food itself wasn't bad. Broth was pretty consistent and tasted good. The pho itself came with a good amount of noodles and meats, too (Pho Dac Biet). Unfortunately, I could tell that the iced coffee was hastily prepared. The temperature consistency was just not there. When I initially started drinking it, I was surprised to find out that there was still an extremely warm layer of coffee at the bottom. Also, the service was rather slow. The slowest parts of service were the lag times I experienced while waiting to order and receiving my check afterwards (sat there for 20 minutes after I finished eating). I don't blame the waitress as she was the only one serving multiple tables at once, but the establishment really needs to take note that dinner hours tend to be much busier than the day. It'd probably be wise to hire at least one more person to help the poor solo waitress out.

0r0hKShbQDJ9kHcpBF13-A.text: Generously portioned, reasonably priced, friendly staffed, freshly prepared, tasty pho, broken rice and other traditional vietnamese dishes.  The setting is plain, but attractive with back lit, color changing wall panels.  The lunches are an especially good deal, with most dishes under $8.  So with all that good, what's the bad?  The service can be a little slow and there's nothing terribly distinctive about the place.  Everything was good, but nothing about the service, dishes, or decor is particularly memorable either.  That said, Squirrel Hill was in need of a quality Vietnamese pho house, and now thanks to Tan Lac Vien, they have  a worthy purveyor of fine pho!

keP2FlpmBsf8Y-ysiowfWg.text: First, I will say that I am actually Vietnamese so I know what authentic Viet food is supposed to taste like. I also come from Southern California where there are entire counties bursting with Vietnamese immigrants opening restaurants. I came with my family and we ordered the bun, com, and pho. The bun and com had good flavor and the meats were seasoned well. However, the pho was disgusting. The broth was tasteless. It was like instant broth. Also, the noodles are completely wrong. They are way too thick. I came for pho, not some kind of wannabe udon. And why they advertise that they are also a Chinese, Japanese and Thai restaurant is beyond me. Clearly they could benefit from sticking to just one type of cuisine.

fUuZTcclqo7WsnbRtzJqqQ.text: I've been to a few of the Vietnamese restaurants here in Pittsburgh and there is a consistent issue with the ethnic foods. The are usually lacking in flavor and that they don't provide the variety of ingredients (ie greens) that many ethnic Vietnamese dishes offer.   However, I had come here on two occasions with friends and was pleased on both ocassions. The first time I came I ordered the Bun Bo Nuong (rice vermicelli with grilled beef) the blend of sweet, salty and spicy from the nuoc mam (fish sauce) blended perfectly well with the ingredients in the bowl.   My next outing was a little more formal. We ordered the spring rolls w/ shrimp and the vegetarian papaya salad as appetizers and the were delicious. you couldn't even tell that the vegetarian ham was vegetarian at all with the texture and flavor. For my entree I ordered the Banh Hoi (woven rice vermicelli) with grilled beef. This came with rice paper that we would wrap in our own DIY spring roll. The assortment of greens that accompanied was great from cilantro, coriander, basil, and other fresh herbs. For desert we had vietnamese coffee and the sticky rice with durian. I'm we acquainted with durian and its smells, however the way that they made the dish, the smell is gone and instead you get the sweet taste of coconut and a hint of the tangy durian taste.   The waitress we had was very nice and informative that night and the owner even had a chance to come over and talk to us about the cuisines. It was a great dinner.  If this place sold Vietnamese sandwiches for lunch, I'd be here way more often. My next try is going to be the pho.

4GKveusgpVpx9TWalZ6eTQ.text: Very good food. I had the make your own rice paper wrap with grilled shrimp. Worth stopping here if you are in the area. The pho is also really flavorful and full of noodles and veggies. Only 4 stars because the place is a little dated.

xEtdhZRyVgLz-GJy57kiSQ.text: F-ing Sucks!!!! After waiting for 30 min to be seated took another 30 just to get some water! Avoid at all costs! Would give it negative stars if I could. Watch the staff too, they try to get out on you

8GFOrIs_WsseP6nQG7H_zw.text: Too salty and some of the ingredients like veggies came from can.  Asked to make it less salty and rather thAn taking the pho back they just brought me a cup of water to pour into it.  Too expensive for the low quality of the food.

Bm3zozIE6PPLi_S1WT4clQ.text: A strong 3 star and one of the best restaurants on this stretch of Murray (which is not saying much).   The place is nice, simple but elegant. The service was competent ,and the dishes were quickly brought to the table. It is reasonably priced ($10-12 for the pho).   The summer rolls were tasty and fresh. The soups were large, and we did not finish them. While the pho was good, the other soup (pork broth instead of beef broth as in the pho) with seafood was rather bland, which explains the 3 stars. The broth was simply not very tasty and the seafood did not add much to its flavor.   Still, I'll be back!

JUCOi17pX_ZWyr0w_sSBrg.text: Good overall Viet. cuisine.  The bun bo hue was on the thin side.  it needs to be a denser/spicy-er broth .  the goi cuon were excellent. about as good as vietnam's pho's .  vietnam's pho is clearly the 'best' vietnamese eatery in pittsburgh but tan lac vien is catching up to them at this rate .

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Better menus pic

2HJNr8vhJxDjC3tg2z_YzA.text: Really clean and delicious food. Just what you hope for when you order. I don't usually order pho (sorry!), but everything else I or my family has ordered has been delicious. I'd especially recommend their grilled pork. Friendly staff, small restaurant.

asa9dSfIy3SUgjAzs_n_cQ.text: Worst experience!  I ordered the lemon grass tofu here because I am waiting my friend.  However, after I finished,  they ask me to order more, otherwise I can not stay here. They even said it's not Mcdonnell and very rude.

uaUpmwh0ct5-GfmdjcLXdQ.text: First time ever for Vietnamese food. Was a little nervous looking at the menu. Only draw back was some of the menu was worn off and unreadable. The waiter was super helpful in directing us to what we wanted and have us his recommendation on his favorites. Had 2 appetizer and 2 noodle bowls. And total was $38 and brought 3/4 off my.soup bowl home. Will definitely go back!!

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Spring rolls.and steamed chicken dumplings
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. 2 noodle bowls and 2 apps $38 so good and waiter was very informative

njIQ_VkG31SesRHQ9D1fhA.text: I loved this place. Great Pho, great cha gio, and a good price if you come for lunch. Sadly I was the only one who decided to come for lunch so I was eating without anyone to eavesdrop on. They give a student discount which is nice. The only thing is, I wish they put more beef in the Pho--just like Vietnam's Pho--both places make me ask "Where's the beef?" overall this is a solid restaurant. I look forward to eating here again and also exploring the other places in the area which all seem authentic.

-A9CNOfbPv6DhV1RD-EYqg.text: We regularly eat here and have tried many things on the menu, and it's all delicious. It's a great place for vegetarians and meat-eaters alike. We never have to wait too long for a seat, and the service is fast and friendly. The BYOB policy makes up for the two dollars signs. It's not the coziest place in the world but the food and service keep us coming back.

PedBI5xOf9hrB-Lrkb_sCA.text: Loved their cha jo. Small portions actually dont seem any smaller compared to the regular ones, especially the amount of noodles! If you are a regular woman (not exceedingly hungry), get a cha jo and a small noodle.

li0CEaJs_FI91e_b2Zfy1Q.text: This place definitely fits into my ADD category of restaurants simply because each dish is really interesting and fun to eat. I don't have that much experience in the Vietnamese realm of food other than Pho,so this was a nice new experience for me me.  We came here for lunch and the special lady had told me that it can take a good amount (:25+) of time to get food here so we came here for lunch with that in mind. When we walked in we were promptly greeted and seated. The friendly staff had only us to attend to in this very small dining room so they were able to answer some of my questions in great detail which I can really appreciate.   For an appetizer we tried an order of the GOI CUON which is simply a fresh summer roll. What is a summer roll? well it is a neat little bundle of fresh veggies and shrimp, it said that it had pork belly in it but I wasn't tasting it which is fine with me for this tasty bundle. Itis wrapped in a rice paper wrapper that gives an appearance of being wrapped in an opaque plastic wrap that is edible. It had a really unique texture and combined with the veggies and shrimp it made for a great delivery device for an appetizer. This came with a large side of some sort of peanut based dipping sauce that I recommend trying, I think some people would be turned off by the sauces brown appearance but it is very good.  For our main dishes I tried something other than PHO, and it was definitely a neat little plate of stuff you can just mix together to your hearts content. It was almost like an adult happy meal for me. It was called COM TAM SUON BI OP LA, or you can call it CT2. I really enjoyed the runny egg that was also on the plate, and before you Pittsburghers get all excited about a runny egg, that I guess is common in a lot of asian dishes??? Who knew. I took a picture of it for yelp so you can take a look at it, it was all fresh and tasty but I thought what the special lady got was hands down one of the best noodle dishes I have had in a long time. It is called BUNG DAC VIET or the BV1. It was a very refreshing dish that I almost could stop sampling hers. Matter of fact after I horked down my dish I went to town on everything she didn't eat. This dish had noodles, salad, cucumber, shrimp, , tasted  like some mint and/or cilantro. But it was a great combo. Now one other thing was that these are pretty large dishes with fresh ingredients, so be prepared and have an appetite or be ready to bring some who with you.   It only took about 15 minutes to get our food so thats really good in my opinion for freshly prepared made to order food. And you may actually learn a thing or two or at least learn how to pronounce stuff on the menu.   Den kiem tra noi nay ra! That's vietnamese for, come check this place out!

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bun Dac Biet (BV1)
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Com Tam Suon Bi Op La (CT2)

_XdT493QJv1UhgtTUU95mQ.text: Had a serious craving for Pho, completely satisfied. Excellent food from the chicken/veggie dumplings to the delicious pho. Ordered the beef and flank steak Pho and it was perfect, light aromatic broth, al dente rice noodles served with a side plate full of cilantro, sprouts and mint. Sooo good. The staff was gracious and helpful despite the packed house. Can't wait to go back.

ATBOBvhXIklxmmqMOj4ygw.text: Both my friend and I experienced a diarrhea after having Pho, though it tasted pretty good.

3DPpOjoakHLHJss1T2PC1A.text: I just recently moved to Pittsburgh and was hesitant about Vietnamese food here since I am from California, and the Vietnamese food in California is superb. However, I must admit I was glad to have stumbled upon this nice little place on Murray Ave. I tried the Pho, and it was very good. The service here is great, the staff is very friendly and will cater to your needs. I'm looking forward to coming back here and trying out their other sure to be delicious items on the menu.

G10mv5ZTaJXqev8WokXvuw.text: Flavorful pho (most around $12) and right amount of spice. Could use more meat however. Crispy pork roll appetizer was delish.

BchfCtg3iJkQ34gTMxqPVQ.text: I am pleased as punch that this restaurant was everything I wanted it to be and more. I've had this place bookmarked for a long time, and finally got an opportunity to check it out. When we were seated (around 5:30), we were the only guests in the place. It was only my second go around with Vietnamese food, and since the menu had so many different types of dishes I'd never heard of I decided to trust her on her choices. Our waitress was extremely upbeat and friendly and was actually fantastic in her recommendations.  My buddy ordered a rice noodle dish with ham, sprouts, and other veggies that was light and tasty, esp when accompanied with the sauce. My dish was phenomenal with two big crepes filled with shrimp, sprouts, pork, and something else and was accompanied by a virtual field of greens, cucumbers, carrots, cilantro, and other healthy stuff! The dish was filling but not greasy which was a nice switch up from most Americanized asian food joints.  For whatever reason I decided to get creme brulee at the end of my deal. What it lacked in texture, it made up for in creamy deliciousness. I was thoroughly pleased. I will definitely visit this place at non peak dining hours, because by the time we left tiny place was packed!

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Creme brulee at a Viet place? Sure, why not!
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. One of the Chef&#39;s specials (rice noodles with ham)
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Vietnamese crepes with the most amazing sauce, ever.

nYEbFntz9HTwSMuIxwGukA.text: We did dinner here recently. I like that it's so traditional and authentic, from the moment you walk through the door until you're filled up with their yummy food. The service is fast and friendly. Even as the tables filled around us, I didn't feel cramped in the dimly lit space. I honestly have zero complaints.   The portions are huge, the options unlimited and everyone I was with was incredibly satisfied. I ordered the Pho Ga (chicken) and I could barely manage to eat half of it, it was massive (and only $10!). I love that you can add as many veggies (or as few) as you like - really altering the dishes to your preference right at the table. My friend had the vegan Pho and the vegetables in it looked amazing. So good. If you're in Squirrel Hill and craving Pho, this is the spot.

N_BrwatSXbbMqNTyYnOIXA.text: Been there twice just to get a fair observation. The food was not terrible but definitely nowhere close to being authentic or good.   However, the service was the worst. This waiter gave me a small ladle to eat pho. And when i asked for a normal soup spoon, he said that he didnt know "what is a normal spoon". When i asked for a smaller spoon, he got irritated and gave me the to-go plastic spoon!!! Very rude and unprofessional. I will never recommend this restaurant to anybody, nor will i ever come back to this place.

WhHdse4AORfPdDWewySCtw.text: There in a Friday night. Place was freezing though it was 37 degrees out. Everyone eating with their winter jackets. Also it was easy to see that it wasn't clean.  Glasses were dirty as was the table. Had to ask for a plate and then later for chopsticks. The crispy spring roll was pretty good and the Pho mediocre. Not a good experience overall and the food was just fair. Place has gone downhill and would not go back.

rjsDBaXFuUH0Oj7imKZMEg.text: Food is good but service is slow.  Last two times we were here.  Most Asian restaurants are normally pretty fast.  We were dinning with little kids so waiting was a factor.

LFBxNh9r3M2B7BZUG1bmfw.text: There was a bug, yes literally a bug( I can even clear see it's legs and half head) in my pho. It is way more Disgusting than I describe. I should have taken picture but unfortunately I only remember to complain but not save some evidence. They immediately took the bug away after seeing it. Guys, this place is not clean. Hope I will not get sick later tonight. Guys, honestly DO NOT GO. Again, DO NOT GO!!! ( alright they replace a new one to me. But if it not because I ask, they were trying to charge me with that one.  I mean at least they should apologize and not ask money for a replacement!!!)

j_7od8fgXxcUcBIW9Q5gLQ.text: I really like their vermicelli dishes, and you get a really big portion for the price. I've only had the pho once but it tasted really bland to me so I have not re-ordered, but my friends do enjoy it so it's probably worth a try. Their quality of food and service are consistently good every time I've been there and I will keep coming back to grab a quick bite to eat in Squirrel Hill.

yEefpzguy1cKFlsS-gRf0Q.text: The place is tiny and nice. I had the typical pho was delicious. The wait staff was limited so it did take some time for us to be served. The waitress was nice and apologetic. It's a nice gem in Sq. Hill

ofrKB26_bmeX1ekcmumGMw.text: We have stopped for a bowl of pho on a cold March day and loved the place. Friendly fast service, huge portions of fresh pho & good prices.

UEXCBSbIpouFnRsrPXjK2g.text: Price - too high Value - not good  Taste - not good Service - fair  I ordered a bowl of pho.  At $12 per bowl I expected more than a few slices of meat and definitely less MSG. It has so much MSG that after the first spoon my tongue is numb. I am definitely going to have a massive headache tonight. I am used to $6.50 to $8.00 for a great bowl of pho. And that's in LA, where supposedly living cost is way more expensive than here in Pittsburgh. The lack of competition has driven the price up and quality down. I am thoroughly disappointed.  As for the service, I asked the waiter for a lime a few times which did not come.   I will not be coming here again.   And there it is the headache.

PkM0ca05kxyxPC7GEMJd3w.text: I finally got to Tan Lac Vien. I ordered gluten-free versions of the chicken pho and, on the recommendation of the server, the shrimp broken rice. My daughter wanted the Pad Thai. (Yes, I know that Pad Thai is not Vietnamese, but she was adamant...)  The pho was good. The broth was hearty and well-seasoned, the chicken was tasty, and the noodles were tender. It came with fragrant fresh herbs. The portion was surprisingly large. I had enough left-overs for an entire second meal! I'm not an expert, but this pho hit the spot!  The broken rice was a disappointment. It was covered in some coating that did not look gluten-free. I hope it was gluten-free because I tried a little. It wasn't a big loss because it didn't taste good at all. We will not order this dish again.  Both my husband and my daughter enjoyed the Pad Thai, which contained a generous amount of chicken. Again, they give you an enormous portion that made a second meal for her as well!  Overall, we're looking forward to our next visit!

bumgJwtYwSDtUFjG9NBXJA.text: Came in for dinner by myself and sat in the aisle. Waitress was very friendly and supportive!  I ordered a BUN DAC BIET (rice noodles) and tasted great. Was just too too too used to the pricing in nyc so I thought this was very pricey (in nyc this dish costs $7 and here it costs $13). Considering i'm not in the city anymore i'll let this pricing slide (: ! I'm just SOOOOO used to getting a big bowl of pho for only $6!!! ):  Regardless of the pricing, food was great.  Had a slight problem with the water... Tasted funny like washed rice water. Told the waitress and felt like she knew something was wrong with it since she promptly took it away... but she got me a new glass and tasted normal.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. $13 worth of goodness, under bun vermicelli, BV1. BUN DAC BIET !!

fjP27PZZhZVRUii2H01fGQ.text: I had lunch here. The waiting time for a waitress to have a seat is at least 4 minutes. The waitress is definitely racist. I didn't get any welcome sentences or smile while all other white customers got. The food is not bad, but the service is more than terrible. I will never come here again.

q5TTN7wosRuBpaYX7a9HfA.text: Food was great. Pho was delicious, honey lime chicken was tender and tasty. Would have loved a kids menu or something to order for the kids.

1ylzUxQ60HTJEk--DbUQRQ.text: So we went there for lunch. Amazing ambience and good service. We ordered pho tofu and marinated pork vermicelli. Both tasted excellent. A Definite must try!!

_OWMmTDa0HuAx3ndBmJgfw.text: Great food, slower service but nothing too bad. Vegan options cover a full page. Casual and worth a visit

GmiqeeoTfvhE8UdvWwfbdA.text: Had the pho and the pork chop. The pho was great--flavorful and clean broth. Spring rolls were on point. However, the pork chop itself fell short on flavor for me. I loved the vegetables that came along side. Their chili dipping sauce was great, too!

6lSM_XHEZAxg9LxzGmvQqg.text: On my first visit here it was a freezing winter day, so I decided to be cautious and order Pho figuring it would warm me right up. It very well did. The quality of the Pho wasn't far off of what I've had on Kingsland Road in London; the only short comings was Tan Iac Vien didn't serve the Pho with red chili peppers and there wasn't as much beef as I have become accustomed to.  The service was attentive and very accommodating.  I liked the small, intimate atmosphere of the restaurant. My friend and I were the second table to be seated which worried him that it was almost empty, but it filled up quickly afterward.

QmPlk26EQruYyxLoByLgJw.text: Took my mom to TLV for the first time 3 wks ago... and we loved it! I liked it to much I had to stop by again about a wk ago :)   Tried the goi cuon, banh xeo, bun bo hue, hu tieu nam vang, com tam dac biet and the sticky rice w/ durian (mmhmm mhm) and they were all so delicious. Portion of those bowls are huge, no joke.   This place is small but there are tables upstairs when it gets busy too or for a big group of parties or something. I don't mind though, def a must try! :)

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bun bo hue!

6d6vM2SH26YBtAH-fXPDBQ.text: I almost hit 5 stars but hate to do this for a single visit.  I will be back very soon to try something else.  I ordered the bun with chicken and fried spring roll.  Everything was perfect.  The noodles were soft and delicious, the chicken marinade was awesome, the sauce was a little sweet and spicy and fishy and yummy and yes!  I'm used to a little pile of peanuts and a lime to squeeze but this isn't really necessary.  I caught some cilantro... more is better for me because I love it.  This is a tiny place so I can imagine showing up and not getting a table.  The service was very good and the prices were ok for Squirrel Hill.  Maybe a little high for the cuisine.  Can't wait to try some more.  It could end up being my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in the 'Burgh.

X7-lxFvYHcWe6V9A19uZsQ.text: Loved this place. Great service. Hot pho. I loved that they put the cilantro, jalapenos, bean sprouts, and lines on the side so you can add them. Some places in Pittsburgh put them all in the soup when they bring it out to the table. I appreciate this because I like my pho the way I like it. It's small and gets crowded quickly l but thats just because of how good it is.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Big bowl of delicious pho . So good.

us-KPyziZh8626aheXu7DQ.text: Stopped in for a very late lunch (4pm?) with my sister, and we both ordered Pho.  I got the Pho Tai Nam combo, which comes with rare and well-done eye round beef as well as flank.  The broth was very nice, we had a plethora of fresh accoutrements (jalapeno, thai basil, sprouts, lime wedges, etc.), and overall the Pho was quite tasty.  My only complaint is that I felt like it was light on the meat... I get at least 50% more beef in my Pho when I get the three-cut combo at Pho Van in the Strip.  We tried the sticky rice with durian dessert.  Durian is a southeast asian fruit that's kind of stinky in smell but has a rich nutty flavor in taste.  Some people find the smell fragrant, particularly if they've grown up having it routinely in Vietnamese cuisine, but I had a hard time getting used to the smell (to be fair, the waiter did warn us about this and had even offered to give us a sample before we ordered it...we only declined because we were in a rush).  Our service, however, was stellar.  We were constantly attended to, our waters were refilled almost instantaneously, and our server was super friendly and helpful.  He was particularly helpful towards the end of the meal when we were a bit rushed to avoid being late to our next event.  I definitely look forward to coming back here (it's a super convenient location if you live or work near CMU) to try some of the other dishes soon!

N2hpESvzFt6EJ-PNYnu4GA.text: Another hidden gem of Pittsburgh, nestled in the deeper ends of squirrel hill.   This is my 3rd time here, and the quality of food has yet to stray from delicious!   I'd recommend the house special pho or the bun bo huei if you like spicy broth. However, if you're looking for something different I'd recommend the broken rice with pork chops! (The rice grains are literally chopped in half)   Definitely check this place out if you're ever in Squirrel Hill!

Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Broken rice with pork chop

zDFCO5uP_WLdDk0oldrY7Q.text: This place is DELICIOUS! Perfect on a winter or fall day. Went with my boyfriend for Valentine's Day a while ago and had the most deliciously spicy pho (I think it was the bun bo hue?) But DO NOT order this unless you can really, really, reallyyyy handle spicy food. Grilled chicken rice vermicelli was also so so delicious and the sauce that came with it was amazing. Server was sweet and patient. Cannot wait to go back to this gem!

4LVXja4Dcev1fBGSZw_eLg.text: Lost our order in the system, very bad service. The waitress was not apologetic, I was not mad but my friend was.

O5MoUj8CnhEJbTnAv9qsRQ.text: I love the pho here,  it is the best I have had in Pittsburgh.  I will stay a regular here and tell everyone I know to come here!

e0RyNwwaM4hdGwTmXxiuTA.text: Horrible service and management - beware!   Disclaimer - we generally like their food.  It's not amazing, but they have some decent dishes.  My concern is with their service -- and their management.  I have had issues with my take-out and delivery orders being incomplete (or flat out wrong) in the past, but they rectified those.  Last night was different.  I called to inform them that my delivery order was incomplete.  First, they questioned whether I was telling the truth.  Then, I was told that they made the food and the delivery driver is to blame for not delivering the full order.  They told me that they were not responsible, that they would not deliver the item to my home (although I could pick it up), and they would not reimburse me.  When I challenged them, I was told that it was too bad, that they were busy, and was hung up on.   I get it -- you're busy.  But how much longer do you expect to be busy when you treat your customers this way?  I won't be returning and hope this makes others think twice, too.

RS8nXMOLKpLxoedlH8T9pg.text: Compared to other Asian fare in the neighborhood, Tan Lac Vien offers meager portions and high prices. The bahn mi was large, but not as good as others I've had.

kmH-YRtjjpELWgnLtzQ5zQ.text: This is definitely my go-to pho place in Pittsburgh after Miss Saigon 99 changed everything to beef broth and lost me as a customer (I don't eat beef). However, the waitress kept rushing my friend and I to sit down, order, pay and then leave and it was a relatively unpleasant experience. Would come for the food, but definitely not for good customer service or a sit down meal when you're trying to catch up with a friend. Made it so unpleasant -- ugh!

4SUIm_iSe5kIiGKrLHvRiw.text: My dad was in the mood for some Vietnamese food, so we stopped by around 6 pm on a Tuesday evening. There were a couple occupied tables, but it didn't look too busy.  We ordered the shrimp paste on sugarcane skewers as an appetizers. I got some pho because I felt cold in the air conditioning. My dad got bun vermicelli. When our appetizer arrived, the waitress explained how to eat it, which I really appreciated. Overall, the food is on par with other Vietnamese restaurants I've visited. Pho portions are huge. My dad's portion looked sizeable, too, but I don't think it filled him up. Then again, I don't think he ate much earlier in the day.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shrimp paste on sugarcane skewers
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pho rare beef and tendon

d-aHX7Pqs0GoJ0W647t6uA.text: I came here with a group, so I had the opportunity to try a few dishes. +1 star for having a decent vegetarian menu, but as for the execution, read ahead.  The pho was OK- nothing egregious or outstanding. It will do. My gripe was with my Bun- the fish sauce was lacking something, and so was the protein and the spring roll. The radishes and carrots were not really pickled at all- it was lightly sweet, and was lacking the tangy crunch it's supposed to have.   The pepper tofu dish was something else- I do not recommend this dish. Just because you order vegetarian, doesn't mean that the food should be bland. Just don't get this- you won't even be finishing the leftovers.

QU2pfynvr1xiDjbC0OUxPw.text: We got turned on to Vietnamese food in Denver, used to go to New Saigon, took my son there when he was 2 weeks old. We called it "Happy Mouth," because that's what you had when you left. I have been on a quest worthy of Shrek for 13 years. I found it.  Tan Lac Vien (translated as New Happy Place) is my new Happy Place. The meats are seasoned perfectly. Right combination of salt and sweet and vinegar and umami. The fish sauce is so appealing I can drink it.  Very nice sized portions, excellent balance of very fresh green herbs and lettuce. We are reeling in delight. They were out of beef, so we had pork. Good quality, not at all chewy. If they would have had beef, I think one of us would have Meg Ryan orgasmic-ed at the table.  We'll be back, multiple times, guaranteed. See you there!  Third time here. Green curry so salty it was inedible. I sent it back. Everything else here seasoned perfectly.

cbWcb0wGEfBnctHtSv4tyA.text: High price low quality.   First off pho and scallops are my 2 favorite foods and would not go back if my pho ga (chicken) was $3 not the $10 they charge.$12 for other pho makes this very high priced and I had to ask for peppers and got almost no basil ( first plate she brought was brown and looked days past serving. Almost no chicken (Shredded in strings I thought the forgot at first). Soup itself was good and noodles where soft so could have been better rating but 3 strikes here.  Waitress could not understand me but sweet. Got app wrong after pointing to menu for all selections. Not worth trying to straiten out so just paid for it. She took it away 2 spring rolls with 1 bite and never asked if I liked them.   To many other great place to go here.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. And so when I ask for peppers this is what I got. 1/3 not bad
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Part of the brown greens I received. 2 really bad pieces taken away before a pic could be taken

u2PQlCYuttSv9Q5cYwNWKw.text: As I was sitting waiting for take out recently, I had to double-check that I had reviewed this Tan Lac before. No, I was mistaken and suprised. We had had a terrible experience before with the service and I'm pretty diligent and prompt about posting either rave or rough reviews.   The layout is a bit strange with a table segregated and close to the front door, but one deals with what they have the best they can.  Tasty vegetarian- friendly food. The veg Pho (Pho Chay) is delicious.  Service is either very slow and/or confused. We've waited for takeout 20 minutes longer than predicted only to walk home with someone else's order. We've dined in, only to have one of our meals arrive 15 minutes after the other, all while other tables are seated, served and have left. No apologies.   Good food, many times, requires a wait, that's understandable. I don't think this place is staffed appropriately. After 5 tries with some sort of service issue, I don't think the taste is enough to bring us back.

Ecx2RDM9bzC-y5jILeQEAg.text: A Vietnamese restaurant that has.....vegetarian options! A rare occurrence indeed. The waiting staff were pleasant and nice. The decor is minimalist but has glowing red lights - looks cool from the outside at night but strange once inside. The music was soft and pleasant, allowing easy conversation with your friends.   The vegetarian pho (pho chay) was good but not amazing, but hey, it's vegetarian and probably hard to make vegetable broth have a spectacular flavor. Mostly, it's great that I can suggest this place for decent food while satisfying my more carnivorous friends. My friend enjoyed his more meaty pho with the caveat that the amount of meat was much less than what you would except in California.  Also: 10% student discount with cash payment at writing time.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Vegetarian Pho (Pho Chay)

e1_wGEjZed2KcQNzSu44iQ.text: I'm not a brothy soup guy, but gave one of the dumpling soups a whirl as it was recommended. It was loaded with flavor and the rice noodles were fresh along with the dumplings. My companion had a standard Noodle bowl with marinated beef and spring rolls. It was also above average made with fresh vegetables and meat.   The environment is dated and feels a tad dirty. The place could use an upgrade, however like most Squirrel Hill locations it's part of the restaurants character.    Service was fast and the prices on par with Pho in a Midwestern city. If I were passing by and in the mood for Pho, I'd stop again. I wouldn't make a special trip for the sole purpose of visiting Tan Lac Vien.

_qiQxAung1Kqzl-00i1QYQ.text: Definitely will be going back when I'm in the Pittsburgh area. The Pho Tai broth was delicious and the portion was perfect!

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

9vb3mk64PedtTyaMAxETuA.text: Best beef dish Ive ever had. Tasty and the sauce set it off! Everything was good and it was a big size portion.

0v-TDb6WWWWTYMpfzxKsUw.text: Good, flavorful Vietnamese cooking with lots of vegan options. I really enjoyed my bun vegan. The tofu and seitan are magnificent. Looking forward to trying more off their vegan menu next time I visit Pittsburgh.

14E8k5Kpow7Fj5ifGtgyuQ.text: Eh.  Stopped in on a bustling and frigid Sunday evening, thinking this would be a quick and cozy option.  We sat down and I was a little surprised that there wasn't any chili oil set out on the table, just sriracha.  Tried two bowls of pho, which arrived after a somewhat lengthy wait.  The food was just okay--definitely not bad, but nothing to write home about, and I'm unlikely to stop in again with so many other fantastic options in the neighborhood.

oLEjXz2w3o8C5W4STBsluQ.text: I was pleasantly surprised by Tac Lac Vien.  We went here on a whim because our first two choices were closed. I'm not an expert on Vietnamese cuisine but my family all enjoyed their meal.  We ordered their Vietnamese, Thai, and (American) Chinese dishes.  The noodle soups were quite good, the Pad-Thai was excellent, and the General Tso's was decent.  We were seated immediately and the prices were reasonable.

zLQbZ8EnzsBeEhBFxVwYmQ.text: We ate there last Saturday. I love the food and they have good service! The staff were friendly and always checking on us. It would be nice if they have a bigger place. We will definitely come back!

lJCP6aiQuovZyfrgKfv6YQ.text: I was curious what the "Pho-1-1" was on Tan Lac, as I heard the musings of delicious Vietnamese food being told on yelp. I ventured out on a chilly friday night to the depths of squirrel hill, swallowed up by rows upon rows of charming old world decor houses and windy-hilly streets.  Tan Lac is situated near some other Asiatic cuisine houses, including the Green Pepper, which I am due to try out soon. Apparently, everyone else got the memo too, OR read my mind in one giant conspiracy...because there was a wait....after eight....I said "isnt this great!" all I wanted was a late plate with my mate for a date!  It turns out, there was a Post Gazette or something article a day before. After sitting on a cold windowsill throne of marble for the better part of forty some odd minutes, my cramped and cold buttocks was escorted to a table with my better looking partner in tow.   By now, our slavering appetites had guided our tongues towards selection, mouthing words of dishes while mentally consuming them with reckless abandon! The spring rolls-Devoured! Peanut sauce tangy sweet and spicy!  The pho arrives! Horns sound, peasants rejoice, banners of epicurean celebration abound! The broth is delicious and savory. After the initial sampling, I tinker with it as an alchemist, shiracha and duck sauce, carefully measured, tasting and musing over the balance of flavor. I was sated, filled, patting my stomach. My girlfriend, the same. Gluttons, we were not, but hungry, we were.   I would love to return and sample some more traditional vietnamese dishes. As for the four stars, it was very good, but lacked the distinction neccessary for five.

1PglRjMOigXRCtZua5BB0w.text: So their menu doesn't have a vegetarian pho option, but wow do they cater to your requests.  Stopped in here late last night with my partner in crime and we had an excellent meal.  They cooked up a mean vegetarian pho that was extremely flavorful, full of tofu and perfect once an appropriate amount of Sriracha sauce (which was brought out promptly, without me asking I might add) was added to the concoction.  The cheese wontons are also quite legit.  Do try them.    Service was fantastic as it was our first time.  Dining here is a very, very safe-bet if you're a fan of Chinese, Vietnamese or Thai.  Furthermore, we really appreciate their kitchen and wait staff serving us at 9:45 (15 minutes prior to close), and waiting for us before we were done.  They certainly did not have to do that, nor would I expect them to, but the fact that they did makes me want to recommend this place even more than I already would.

fk67rOjeA6v7EKKyTh8osQ.text: This place was great! I am a vegetarian, so I am sometimes hesitant about Vietnamese food, because even if there aren't chunks of meat, it is usually hidden somewhere. I explained this to the waitress and she basically created a dish for me! My mom got the N1 Pho and she said it was delish too. Two thumbs up (and I almost never say that).

0iqzvhdc6-fVpg8o2ubE-Q.text: If you love Pho as much as I do, this is the place to go in Pittsburgh. Pho is one of those dishes where every step counts, and taking shortcuts really affects the final product. I'm glad to say, Tan lac Vien doesn't take any shortcuts with their preparation.  The additions included a nice selection of the usual suspects, bean sprouts, cilantro, thai basil, and hot pepper, as well as culantro, which was an unexpected delight. Sriracha and Hoy Sin were also provided.  The service was fantastic, in no small part because the owner was working the front of the house, while her husband was in the kitchen. She seemed very nice and accommodating, and even though the menu indicates 'no substitutions' was glad to make changes when requested (to fit our dietary restrictions).   The restaurant itself is small, but don't be mistaken, there is additional seating available upstairs, (about another 30 seats).   Of the over 30 establishment's I've had Pho in, across five states, this was the best single bowl of Pho I've had.  I've only visited once (so far) but already I can't wait to go back.

MS4MnBXm9dCMcIv8vFiozg.text: Solid Vietnamese food with some Chinese options and a large vegan/vegetarian selection.  Functional atmosphere and quick, friendly service.  Prices are okay, not fantastic.  Worth a visit if you're in the mood for Vietnamese cooking.

SwKBBuH-JREVjEbuU04biA.text: Very eager to return to this little eatery in Squirrel Hill - had a great first experience here, as well as in tasting pho! Certainly now one of my new favorite dishes. This restaurant is a rad little retreat to enjoy some talk and warm pho with a small group of friends. The service was very nice. I ordered the vegetable pho; a dish I totally recommend, especially to vegetarians. Plenty of mushrooms! I really enjoyed it, as it was very flavorful. Tan Lac Vien has really interesting and great tasting flavors, sauces, and spices - we will be back soon!

rc5hd8XfTyu-D3SUAuSijA.text: First things first, they have a vegetarian menu! That option is awesome! Their food is also really good too. My sister ordered the wraps, which she enjoyed. Although, we were terrible at assembling them. Its just like making spring rolls, and we are terrible at doing that. I ordered the mixed vegetables in garlic sauce, which I enjoyed as well. This place also gives you a good amount if food. Just be ready to make your own spring rolls/wraps if you order the wraps. Its a little further walk for squirrel hill, but go and try it.

Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Rice wraps and water to dip them in
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Wraps

jzoIMm-YQZc9Sn0d9vol7w.text: Hey now, I was born in Vietnam so I certainly Pho.  I have eaten at many many Pho establishments across the US.  The Pho special (N1) overall was only average. It lacked the normal Pho punch. There was adequate amount of meats, but the broth was weak. $13 for the bowl is on the high end, especially given that it's located in the suburb of PIT. It is a bit of a hole in the wall, but that usually means the ownership is more concerned with quality and authenticity of food over decor. Not here apparently. The waitstaff was pleasant and attentive. I recommend looking elsewhere for Pho. Surely Pittsburgh has more to offer elsewhere.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. menu
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pho Special.

Kdjat33q9lZIQvDAAopcoA.text: Delicious food! Everything tastes fresh and light, but had very generous portions. I highly recommend the Pho Chicken.

YkzENKZBoB1MmtTz90Uesg.text: Ate there and had a wonderful meal--pho that was done very well, with nice beef and tendon. This is a family-run business; they've created a cozy little place to go and enjoy high-quality Vietnamese meal.

pXGV6Lrqs68B71s8BLKuqA.text: I'm so glad this place opened up on Murray. I can't speak for the other items on the menu, but they serve their pho is MASSIVE bowls with a side plate of all your add-ins: sprouts, culantro (amazing!), thai basil, limes, and jalapenos.   I intend to go here again and again whenever that pho craving hits!

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pho Ga - To die for!

NOu1WciPWMKis09EKUBJcw.text: Our favorite Vietnamese place in the city. We always get their stir fried dishes and the spicy Bun Bo Hue. The stir fried dishes always come extra spicy, just as we like them and full of fresh vegetables, and the broth of the Bun Bo Hue is extremely flavorful. I do recommend attempting this only if you have a high tolerance for spice. It's deliciously spicy - definitely not an Americanized version. Very satisfying, especially on a cold day. We've also tried their dry noodles and regular pho, both very good too. Portions here are very generous - we never need an appetizer to start, but would like to try some options some time. Overall, we really love this place. Fuss-free and quick service makes it even better. And if you're a student, you get 10% off your meal if you pay with cash!

ag7Xad0TUB0EYZQjuK3pDg.text: So overall, the food was awesome, I was just upset with their ability to keep things "in stock."   I ordered hibachi steak and shrimp originally and the kind lady informed me they were out of steak. So I ordered the chicken and shrimp.   (Hibachi is known to come with the creamy shrimp sauce, and it said it did in the menu.)   Well, I receive my food and everything looks great, she then informs me they are out of creamy shrimp sauce...  I was so upset because that was the only reason I ordered the hibachi!  I was offered an alternative sauce that was good but not the same.   And I wasn't offered money off on my bill. That's what makes me upset overall.   Food still tasted great...I was just in a sour mood the whole time.

GyE7WVxoNeCeXGv0Hs60-Q.text: I came here for a meetup event, my first time for both this group and for the restaurant, so I did not know what to expect. The waitress who took our order was very knowledgeable not only about what was on the menu but also in knowing the names of the dish in Vietnamese.  I ordered a spring roll stuffed with ground pork and some Vietnamese spices with fish sauce which I found excellent and exotic tasting. For my entree I ordered crepes stuffed with bamboo shoots and some meat (I forget what kind). It was a decent dish but a bit too messy and difficult to eat. For dessert, I had the sticky rice with duri that I found out of this world. The duri, which was like a pudding with coconut, was excellent and not too sweet like typical desserts.  The service was excellent as the waitress was friendly and very thorough in describing the dishes not to mention providing recommendations, and the hostess was also very pleasant. My favorite dishes were the spring roll appetizer and the dessert. I'd like to come back to try their stews.

WZMP7TNGQGYWfpDBYLOE2Q.text: I love to order Pho from here. I love the taste! I usually order it to go so I can relax and enjoy at home. The food is always ready for me when I arrive so its a quick transaction. Great for small groups or a date. Not ideal for large parties though.

f-5ZWRzeaMAtqEHZB0HRpw.text: Here for an extended period for work and back home I have the best spot for Pho, Lang Van.  While I have been here in Pitt thought, Tan Lac Vien has filled my void for good Pho.  My favorites are the Pho Ga or Veggie Pho.  This has become my go to spot for comfort food.

ipBjjXRqcoaGmKzduyohUw.text: The food was good, but we was the first customer in the restaurant and it was kind of OK service.  The server gave me the glass that on top it has been ruin, so I ask for the straw. Because I don't want to cause any problem and we want to get out as fast as possible. I should try maybe another chance.

OCP2zA3vgipG9RgDaUtRjA.text: This is my favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh. Not just Asian restaurant but overall favorite! Every single thing I've eaten here has been fabulous. The wait staff will recognize you and know your appetizer order if you come more then once a week ;-)  On a cold winter day the Pho will warm you right up. The broth is rich and tasty and the plate of veggies are super fresh.  The House special Bun vermicelli is my second favorite. A bowl of noodles but no broth, fresh veggies, spring roll, and choice of grilled protein all smothered in their house made fish sauce (which I've seen my boyfriend drink straight!) And then there's the Com Tam, broken rice dish...yum! The crispy spring rolls, fresh summer rolls, and steamed chicken dumplings are the best! And there's more than just Vietnamese food! They do a stellar all white meat General Tso's chicken, as well as Thai curry and Chinese noodle dishes. Oh and they have vegetarian and vegan options! Never had a bad meal and we'll keep going back for more!

oZLu8EQ6EBWAGP_hb9z-_Q.text: No music, kind of dirty and food was just OKAY. Definitely not the best Vietnamese in town.

taNZNiG5NsyblkIm9Iio8Q.text: 2.5  I'm sorry - I hate to give a bad review because the server who took care of us here was so nice, but the pho just wasn't up to par.  Pho broth to me should be aromatic.. the one here didn't have the herby, earthy aromas that pho usually has from the star anise, etc. It definitely wasn't plain, but just didn't feel it had any depth of flavor. According to my bf (viet guy) it was just added fish sauce.  The meatballs in my bowl were good, pho noodles were soft, and the portion was very generous. I liked the decor, the ambiance, quiet and good for conversation. A little steep in price for a bowl of pho (dac biet $13), so may or may not come back for a second try  Food: 2.5 Everything else about the dining experience: 4.5 Overall: 3

The spring roll was just ok. The crispy rolls were better, not great, just better. Just not worth the money in my opinion. Sorry.

We got the beef & meatball pho, which was incredibly flavorful.  We also got shrimp broken rice, which was like deconstructed fried rice (all of the ingredients served separately).

5eGjzpnlVq98OOndUBABPg.text: The bun with lemongrass marinated pork is my favorite meal of all Pittsburgh restaurants.  Fresh and flavorful.  The portion is big but you won't feel terrible even if you eat it all.  Food perfection.

mS79uuywsJB3BXENIWsXLQ.text: First time trying Tan Lac Vien was 2.5 years ago and  my husband and I weren't thrilled with the food at all, especially after living in Philly and New York where there are tons of great Vietnamese restaurants to choose from. Since it was such a cold day today, we were craving some pho and decided to give it another shot. Two and a half years ago I would've given it 2 stars but the food has gotten better and service was excellent. We had the crispy spring roll with seasoned pork, pork chops over broken rice and the pho special. They either have a new chef or changed their recipes because the food definitely tastes better than it did before. The pork chop and the fish sauce dipping sauce (nuco mam cham) was much more flavorful but I thought the pho was just average. My husband also occasionally stops by here to pick up some Vietnamese coffee to go and it's one of his favorites. The food's not the best we've ever had but I'm glad we have another go-to place for decent Vietnamese food since it's such a rarity in Pittsburgh.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

3MOQjUedMeBrgMMroTzjaQ.text: I recently moved to Pittsburgh and have been lacking Vietnamese food that is so abundant all around back in Texas. I decided to give this restaurant a try since it was near by to me.... The one star attached was because I had to give a star. I can't believe this restaurant is even open still, back at home in DFW, Texas a place this bad wouldn't last a month. The foods were bland and prepared half assed. it took them 50 minutes to get my assorted grilled meats plate out. Not only that, it even took them a whole 30 minutes to bring out pho to my friends who were in town visiting me!! Never again, this place is disgusting and gives Viet foods a bad reputation.

KmIDeqS1fAGNgFsF_LNovQ.text: The restaurant looked promising enough to be a authentic Vietnamese restaurant, but at last I will have to pass on this restaurant from now on; because its just not up to my Vietnamese food standards.   The traditional/everything-included-in-it pho was decent; if you drown it in the hoisin sauce and sriracha, otherwise the broth contains an overwhelming scent of cinnamon and star anise.    The bun bo hue was the biggest disappointment thou. I'm was looking for a restaurant that can make my all time favorite soup in each city that I go to. This one looked so good and the meats included were tasty and cooked correctly. BUT what was suppose to be a rich spicy heavenly broth...tasted more like a cube of chicken bouillon in hot water with some chili oil. Tasty, if you were looking for a spicy chicken noodle soup with pork stuff in it.   So sad. Oh well, my search will go on for a good Vietnamese restaurant I can adore.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Looks like bun bo hue but tasted nothing like it. It&#39;s like someone just threw in a cube of chicken bouillon and called it a day.

BQFuRWi6g1tZflS_hOOVTQ.text: I've been looking for Vegetarian Pho in Pittsburgh, and Tan Lac Vien seems to have the best around. The Pho Chay is excellent, but there is an extended list of vegetarian options that will keep me coming back.  Our service was excellent, and in fact, our waiter recommended the Com Tam Chay, which was delicious.  Our table was uncomfortably close to another table, and there was no music upstairs, so we were not able to talk as freely as we would like, but I think this would depend on where you are seated.  On the whole, the restaurant is comfortable and inviting.  Our steamed vegetarian dumplings seemed overcooked, they were mushy and overcooked, but this was the only miscue in the kitchen. Delicious food at a reasonable price.

dTYDuMhdiqSrLTe3cB7MQw.text: Probably the worst Asian restaurant I tried in Pitt. The pho was okay. But the spring rolls I ordered were not fresh, they were deff made from the last day. The rice noodles inside was super soft and smashing, the skin is hard and cold. The person who made it came out with attitude... i also ordered the dessert, the sticky rice is microwaved hard. Cannot chew on it, I guess they messed up the timer... other than the noodle, not worth to order...

Is0uMoxHGxMc_t-7qs3LHg.text: The Pho with chicken is sooooo so good. Second time back and I'm in love! I added a little hoisin and Siracha to give it some heat. The chicken dumplings are nice too.

gE7tenLK455yohZ3AX7vWg.text: I visited Tan Lac Vien today with a friend for lunch.  Of three places I suggested that I'd bookmarked in SqHill, my friend chose this one.  For my part, I welcomed her suggestion to visit, since it had been quite awhile since I'd last had pho.  We ordered cha gio (spring rolls) to split ($5), and we each ordered a lunch sized bowl of pho ga (chicken pho; $8).  The spring rolls came out within 5 min., and were quite good.  They were appropriately crispy on the outside, and flavorful and well-textured on the inside.  While they were great on their own, they came with an accompanying sauce that added some additional flavor and heat.  Both of us enjoyed them very much.  As for the pho, its broth was rich and savory, and stood quite well on its own, although I added some sriracha and hoisin to add some extra interest to the second half.  The proportion of noodles seemed about right, and the fresh herbs were a nice accompaniment that we both took advantage of.  It could just be my American palate, but the amount of chicken included seemed a bit stingy, though it was white meat.  Again, both of us enjoyed the pho, though both of us are far from being pho experts (this was her first time eating it and my second).  Overall, we were quite pleased with our experience at Tan La Vien.  The price seemed pretty reasonable, given the food quality and portion size, and we were able to get an additional 10% student discount, thanks to her (I no longer qualify, unfortunately). The setting and service were fine, as well, so no complaints there.  If you're hungry for a bowl of pho in SqHill, check this place out--it doesn't disappoint!

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Cha gio (spring rolls)
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bowl of pho w/ toppings (lunch portion)

YcGBcH89Nhw7HIohfFhHDg.text: Reviews aren't wrong! This place is fantastic. Sometime the language barrier makes it a little hard but still well worth it. Try it if you like Vietnamese food. Mmmmmmmmm

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Love the crepes

QCaqisLcffAn3_dH7OJ7SA.text: My favorite pho place in Pittsburgh! The food is delicious and the service is quick. I just ordered takeout and forgot to ask for hoisin sauce. But I got home and opened my container to find a little to go hoisin/sriracha mixture. Exactly what I wanted!

Fw3Cu2vlfAdRNqDDKeNK_Q.text: I love Vietnamese food and was really excited to try out this place when I saw all the great reviews. The restaurant itself was pretty small, but has a nice feel to it when I first walked in. However, the waitress sat us at this table for two in this awkward narrow hallway near the entrance. Personally, I thought our waitress was kind of unfriendly and unprofessional.   I ordered "Bun Bo Hue". The portion was huge with a lot of meat. The broth was just right and the noodles weren't too soggy. The only downfall to this bowl of "bun bo hue" was that it lacked banana blossoms--a must have. Also, I thought it was a lot pricier comparing to all the other Vietnamese restaurants in Pittsburgh. It was good, but I don't think it is worth it for the price.  Overall, Tan Lac Vien lost a star for poor service, and another star for being overpriced.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pho Dac Biet
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bun Bo Hue

m3Ou0HDVrYp5wDPBxo1Gtw.text: Hands down the best pho I've ever had in my life. Easily the best in Pittsburgh omg.  I got N5 (pho with beef, it's a soup), good portion size and fairly cheap price for dinner! $10  one spoonful, and said "it's so good I could cry" Then someone told the waitress that and she was like "aww that's the best compliment anyone could ever give" But seriously guys. It's so good. (Personally I despise cilantro, so none of that for me.) but yes. Their portions are huge but literally our whole table finished their bowls. I can't really describe the experience except for the fact that it was absolutely delicious and you all need to go

fgIpWSSJ4vShCmuW3jJn7Q.text: Yet another update for Tan Lac Vien, but only because my most recent visit was different enough from my last one to warrant another comment. It seems that they have their new menus in place now, which is a great replacement from what they had before. Lots of nice pictures which reinforce their relatively large selection in comparison to other Vietnamese places in the city.  I specifically ordered a grilled pork banh mi to go, which was not originally offered a while back. For $6, you get a fair-sized sandwich, probably smaller than what you'd find at Subway or Jimmy John's, but with a very different taste. All the standard ingredients of carrot, daikon, cucumber, cilantro, and jalepeno were included, along with the sauce that makes the sandwich taste distinctly Vietnamese. Adding to this medley of flavors was the perfectly grilled pork, which has been consistent across other dishes like the com tam and bun as well. There aren't that many banh mi places in Pittsburgh, but this is definitely a winner in my book.  The only small concern I could bring up is that there was a bit more sauce than is usually found in banh mi, so it was a bit messy with the sauce dripping out at the other end. But it wasn't overwhelming at all, so it's not a huge issue.

8w0wfy1lha-Y5HQDGQBQlw.text: This is a pretentious-Ghetto version of Vietnamese food. Its overly Americanized, overpriced pseudo Asian BullSht.   Don't let the phony veg options allure you, I guarantee no satisfaction.   The servers were creepy bums too.

haEJHP5vCkz5IOBk5H8x1g.text: In the heart of squirrel hill. I've been here several times and it's a little inconsistent for my liking. I've been on both extreme sides of the stick. Food is always pretty good but the service has been from awful to amazing. I suggest take out. You won't be disappointed. Their summer roll is amazing!

y7-qHXpfGja1Ft9OWKo_tA.text: Pho is such a weather and mood food-- meaning  1. Are you hungover? 2. Is it gloomy or raining?  If you answer yes to either of these questions, that means pho will solve your problems!   They've redone their menus to be more visual-- you're able to see all the different types of food. But of course I stuck with pho since question #2 was a yes. Big bowl of soup with hearty broth. This broth is probably one of the best in Pittsburgh-- tried the other places in the strip, and none live up to this. Generous portion of noodles, could have a bit more meat in it. Was way full after, barely had room for the bun I was splitting-- so we ended up taking that home.  For a CMU student... This might be a bit of a trek without a car-- but well worth it! Make sure to take a guava candy on your way out!

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. N1 aka Pho special has all the meats-- flank, meatball, tripe
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. BV1 aka Bun Vermicelli with shrimp and chicken (the special)

mZOH5xGAzZvzwv8HGf89ZA.text: If you are looking for good Vietnamese cuisine in the Pittsburgh area, I highly recommend this restaurant.  Visiting from NY, we took our daughter (who attends college here) and a few of her friends.  We had reservations for 7:30 but the people at the table they had intended for us were apparently lingering a LONG time.  So, while we had to wait close to 30 mins, the staff were very attentive, apologetic and nice; they managed to set up a special table for us and they also gave us complimentary desserts! The food here was very good - better than many places in NY - and it was casual but with a very warm ambience.  A few people had the soup (pho), which got good reviews, the steamed dumplings were excellent, and the bun that I had was very good.  It's refreshing (based on my experience in the Burgh) to find a place where you ask for the food spicy . . . and they actually make it spicy!  Good job.  The crepe dish was deep fried but very good and not overly greasy.  Interestingly, we had stopped by the evening before for take-out, and they said it would be an hour wait - seriously? for take-out??  A place like this would never survive in NYC, but hopefully it will here because it is a real gem! Just goes to show - if you serve great food and are good natured, people will be very forgiving of miscues.  I am sure we will be back!

hGrCwiqxPZzTCRbbmrn9Dw.text: had dinner here last night. we shared the lemongrass tofu for a starter. my husband got the pho, and i got the noodle soup- with chicken and chicken broth. all dishes were amazing. fresh, full of flavor and the owner was so sweet and welcoming. i can't wait to go back. def the best pho in pittsburgh.

VBusWAEjJV3ymCNElcH7lQ.text: My family and I love pho, but this isn't the best place we've tried. It is good, but there are better one's in the city. The service is good, and the staff is friendly. The vegetarian spring rolls were delicious! They are a bit on the pricy side. I don't think the price and the quality add up.

yZUAAG5Q5U8FReamoe67WA.text: Ambiance: Somewhat small space with only 5-6 tables, seats maybe 20 people. They place tries to take on a modern spin with decorative wall panels and bold colors but the yellow paint and plentiful scuffs on the walls kind of make this place feel a little run down. This was compounded by them seating us next to a door with chipped paint and a removed doorknob like a ghetto closet. It was not reassuring to see no vietnamese on the menu and our server didn't speak vietnamese. He was friendly but was also one-track minded and tunnel-visioned so it was hard to get his attention. Even when looking around, he failed to note when glasses were empty or when meals were close to being done (so he can prep a check).   Food: We started with summer rolls which were small but tasty, most places I go to serve 3 half-shrimp per roll instead of 2. The rice wrapper wasn't chewy though and the peanut sauce was savory with a slight kick. For the main, I had the pho special which was good but odd. Authentic pho is really just a simple beef broth which should be rich, savory, and salty with a pick-your-own-adventure of herbal components. While the broth here was savory, it was not quite concentrated enough to be called rich. The odd part is that they add anise, cinnamon, and other spices that unnecessarily complicate a normally humble dish, let the beef broth shine on its own! Portion-wise, the dish was fine although I grew up in San Diego where you can get pho for literally half the price they charge here. My wife had the grilled pork broken rice which was OK although the fish sauce was notably weak/dilute.  Raised by vietnam-born chinese parents in california and having visited vietnam, I can honestly say this is NOT authentic and over-priced. The food is fine and tasty but I'd recommend exploring other places first if you're looking for a True vietnamese experience.

EgnViEQCnyebclwWPs43Sg.text: Had the N16.  Tasty.  Will be back.  Must try additional items to give a fair review.  Large menu.   Was busy.... it was Saturday night... Slow service I received my dish long before my dinner partner. Always uncomfortable when that happens.  Will update soon.

E9I4S1qowrsHzjL-Fl79ww.text: Overpriced for what it is. If you're looking for cheaper pho that's better then go to Pho Van. I've been here and ordered 8 times total. A couple times, when I went to the restaurant to eat, the noodles were in a big clump, which I get that pho restaurants don't always cook their noodles fresh but it was kind of a turn-off. Anyway, we all know that pho is the best hangover food and this was close to my house. It's just OK!

OZsH1VPzYrFvKb1brmQMDw.text: A rare stop in Squirrel Hill brought me in here. The cold didn't hurt either, because I really wanted pho. I ordered the pork meatball pho. I thought it was okay, but the broth could have used some more flavor.  I ended up adding a bunch of sriracha and doctored it up to my liking. So while it wasn't the best pho I've had in my life, it did the job on a cold day!

d7dAW8ftBySjeM2uhFz2Ow.text: It's a ok. Been here before for take-outs pho, and dine in as well. Nothing really stands out. For some reason they have a "temporary menu" today, not sure what is going on/what changed. (So photo attached)    I had a rice noodles with spicy lemongrass soup (n15). Soup and the meat were good. But the rice noodles were soft and bland.   BV1 was good. The crispy pork roll was good. Pork and shrimp was good. Noodles were ok.   BH6 was interesting. It has the dry thin slides of rice sheets that you place in water to soften, then lay it on the plate. Put lettuce and meat inside and do your own roll.   Will I be back? Most likely. Will I have an urge to come to this place? Most likely not. It's the only Vietnamese restaurant in Squirrel Hill, so I certainly wish them the best and hope they are here to stay.

lehkF04bpxIV_cRjUYKrCQ.text: I'm not sure what all the bad reviews are about, my family really enjoyed this place. Everything we tried was delicious. In particular, the mango and shrimp salad was excellent and their pho broth was very flavorful (I prefer mine with some spices, which theirs had). We will definitely be coming back.

zJepSsZucshQjToEVL9OCg.text: 3 components make pho: broth, herbs and fresh garnishes, and noodles and protein. All three components need to be done well or the pho won't be good. Well this place hit all three components out of the park. I'm more than super impressed as good pho is hard to find. Light golden delicate  beautiful pho broth you could drink all day. Some of the herbs were a gamble on freshness but the majority (and the freshness of the garnishes) made up for a few wilted pieces. Chicken pho for the win. I almost didn't come here due to distance but I'm so glad I did! A must try for pho fans.

8u8jYBDntQHPUTkHvTaUjA.text: Perfect place for a casual warm dinner on a cold, rainy evening. The server was kind to get a table ready in the back away from the front draft. The chicken pho was hot and tasty and warmed me up. The lemon grass tofu was tasty with a little spice. The menu had many vegetarian and vegan options as well.

BLWDp4E8HE8WScS3d-WLNA.text: Bad service. Waited little over hour just to get the food. Server dude is rude and never came once to refill the water. After the long waiting, I asked the server to check up on my food and his face expression changed and began to show aggression. Pho was decent but it's not worth it to pay my own money and receive bad service.

Blql1ELHA88JSeB1n3zy6w.text: Great pho and fast takeout. Each order came with a beautiful amount of greens sprouts and sauces. Beef pho could have come with more meat.

7t0j1N4irVsyIkPPCbHA1g.text: I ordered for delivery: (1) Pho with flank and beef noodle soup and (2) fresh rolls. There wasn't ONE SINGLE LEAF OF BASIL OR MINT in the entire order. The spring rolls also came with no dipping sauce. They were just two pieces of shrimp wrapped with a single leaf of iceberg lettuce and rice noodles (no herbs, no carrots, no dipping sauce as shown in the picture for ordering). The pho came with no herbs and I asked for hoisin and hot sauce on the side which was ignored. The broth was good so it leads me to believe it would be a better experience dining in but the delivery is crap. 100% not worth it.

7gAtGUlVcqcWNuRL0fNOeA.text: Came here for my first pho experience in Pittsburgh, drawn in by the large vegetarian/vegan menu.  There were only 1 or 2 other tables for Sunday lunch around noon, and our party of 4 was seated quickly, but the place had definitely filled up by the time we left.  I ordered the PHO CHAY, while the rest of my table had the house special PHO DAC BIET, the PHO TAI, and the GENERAL TSO'S CHICKEN.  I had wanted to try a couple of different things for my first visit using the lunch menu, since it was great that it was available even on a Sunday, but the options were pretty limited--no stir-fries that were Vietnamese style and not a lot of vegetarian options.  Oh well.  I was not in the least disappointed with my vegetarian pho.  It came with plenty of vegetables, and the broth tasted DELICIOUS and very naturally sweet.  I was super impressed with the depth of flavor that they were able to create in a vegetable broth.  In fact, I tried my fiance's beef/tripe broth and actually preferred mine.  We both enjoyed the hell out of our dishes and would definitely repeat.  Our friends, who weren't first-timers here, really liked their food as well.    Our table was provided a shared plate of the usual garnishes--basil, cilantro, sliced jalapenos, lime wedges, a heaping pile of mung bean sprouts, and culantro, which I've actually never tried before.  Perhaps the prices were a little steep for pho, as others have said, but the portions were so generous that all 3 of us who ordered pho all had significant leftovers.  We received our food fairly quickly, but service was a bit spotty throughout, which was the one subpar area of our experience.  Perhaps it was simply due to the arrival of the lunch rush, but our meal was checked on an excessive number of times in the first few minutes after we received our food, but we had trouble getting the check by the end, even after actively asking for it.  Our server also made it a point to tell us while we were ordering that they didn't have bubble tea--even though none of us mentioned it?  Um...okay?  She also failed to tell me that the tofu in my pho would be fried, which I'm not a fan of and had pointedly asked about.  "It's soft and fluffy tofu," she had told me.  It wasn't.  It was firm, pressed, and fried.  Next.  I know I sound super picky, BUT inconsistent service will never dissuade me from a tasty meal.  I'll be making my rounds to try other Vietnamese joints in Pittsburgh, but I'll definitely be back, Tan Lac Vien.  In the meantime, the owners might want to consider updating their online menu--it's pretty different from the one I was shown in the restaurant, especially for the section for us Veggies.  Just a thought.

5pRgUDwtBPqqx03BtBooJg.text: Delicious pho. Huge servings. Couldn't finish my bowl :) authentic.   You know your eating at a great pho place when you can eat the broth with out needing to add additional sauce :)

Dye8Ap1eNmCRv4qVle08OA.text: I love Pho! The vegetarian pho (Pho Choy) was fantastic and I will absolutely be back. The broth was so flavorful and was full of noodles, tofu, and variety of veggies. The edamame was standard and delicious.   Service was fast and friendly. This decor could use a little updating/remodeling as is common with many older small establishments such as this but the good food is worth it.   You have to try this place of you too like Vietnamese cuisine!

1EhgsAVpHKINsPRzNPqsQw.text: This place was just ok. Don't get me wrong it was a solid bowl of pho, but for the price I expect more. A bowl of pho is about $12-13 which is a bit pricier than I'm used to. For this price I expected more meat. Otherwise our waitress was really friendly! Side note I wish this place had a better ac system because we were sweating more than usual for eating hot soup.

DjEibbgESVbYM5dNMNNcMw.text: Lately I've been on a quest to find the best pho in Pittsburgh. A friend recommended that I try this place.   As I walked in I wasn't expecting the restaurant to look this way. It's very small with a dungeon feel. I felt like I was in a secret restaurant underground. It was small but that doesn't bother me. It's a nice little place. The guy who seated us was very nice and gave me literally a minute to look at the menu.  I was surprised how much they charged for pho. It's just broth noodles and meat, right? I was thinking, if I'm paying that much it better be the best pho I ever had!   Started off with the crispy spring rolls. It was fried perfectly! Golden brown and not burnt. And the dipping sauce was very tasty.  The pho came out momentarily. Big bowl, lots of noodles, and meat. For me, pho is all about the broth! Unfortunately, it lacked flavor. I was underwhelmed and while the broth looked yummy it lacked that broth-y star anise flavor that I was looking for. I lightly doctored up the soup to give it some flavor with some hoisin sauce. Not a fan of the rare beef cut because it had a slight "dirt" taste to it.   Although the pho lacked flavor, I wouldn't say it is bad. It's good but not the best I've ever had. I would definitely return and recommend it to people who are in the area.

Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

Pj0vZ3na6OmzqSP6lS6-jQ.text: Stopped in between the lunch/dinner time for a late lunch. The space isn't the cleanest and our server let us know that they didn't have any pho beef prepped. Which was the only reason we came. But she ended up coming back and telling us that she was wrong. The pho had good flavor but just a little bit too salty for me. The spring rolls were delicious too!

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

rx9NlcqVjuTqIpBMB1pJQQ.text: I was apprehensive about trying this place out after seeing the ridiculous prices for pho. They charge $13 for the special (dac biet) while other places charge around $9-$10. Yes, those few dollars do matter to me. But let me tell you, those few dollars are so worth it because Tan Lac Vien has the best bowl of pho you'll find in Pittsburgh!  My husband and I came here on a whim on a bitter cold day, figuring pho would warm us up. What I really like about this place is that it has a rather large Vietnamese menu, not just pho, although I couldn't bring myself to try anything else when the weather outside was in the single digits. We ordered the veggie spring rolls, and pho for each of us. The spring rolls came out on a large plate atop a variety of veggies (lettuce, cucumber, carrot, cilantro and basil), which can be used to roll up your rolls in, despite it looking like garnish. I really like that they serve it up with these veggies because it reminds me of how my mom serves her spring rolls: with a plate of greens for wrapping. Taste-wise, they were good but I would much prefer the full flavor from the pork spring rolls. But for $5 for two pork spring rolls, that's a bit steep when you only get about 2-3 bites out of one. And for the star of the show, the pho was the closest to my mom's I've ever had. The portion was large, the broth was clear and aromatic, and it didn't make me super thirsty afterwards (=little to no MSG, yay!). The meat wasn't as plentiful as I would like but it was enough to fill me, so no complaints.  The space is rather small, and the layout is a bit strange with two tables in the front of the restaurant and more tables in the back. Service was very good as several waitresses came by to assist us, without ever repeating questions. It's like they all talked to each other and knew what was taken care of and what was not. Overall, I really enjoyed Tan Lac Vien and I would definitely like to come back to try the other menu items!
