-3XQFnzniNHu7um3g3sRMQ.text: Went to Tan Lac Vien last week with my Father and we both loved the food!  Pho broth was the best I ever tasted.  No kidding.  And the noodles with veggies and chicken was delicious, says Dad.  Both dishes were presented beautifully.  The waitstaff was helpful and pleasant.  We've already recommended this place to others and we'll be back.  How 'bout working on the decor.  The black panels aren't working for me.  Some Vietnamese scenes would be so much better.  Maybe those embroidered panels.

oo2ieZ3fAR2IpvZob77CDA.text: Great Vietnamese food at great prices! I got the pho with chicken and the steamed dumplings appetizer for $16 total and it was fabulous! The service was fast even though it was a pretty busy night. The restaurant is small with minimal decorations, but nice for a casual dinner. For bigger parties there is a room in the back, but otherwise it's better for parties of 4 or fewer due to the small space.

5-qonqHQ4X8QYTJALw-UUg.text: Not bad. I enjoyed my chicken pho and the appetizer rolls were quite delicious. I'll be back.

Wpq4NeoHMMYxX3128udwxg.text: Delicious. Fresh awesome customer service the girls are always sweet! Order the summer roll. Fried spring roll. The rare beef pho and the grilled pork ham mi!!! Totally killer.

Km3reUJkWxccC6SGhXcbiA.text: I have tried a lot of vietnamese restaurant, this one is just so so. The roll is good, but the pho, not as delicious as I expected.

_pJqWWOdCg9rfQ0Y9wuOvQ.text: My experience was the place was kind of small and needed some work but the food was good and Iwill be going back.

7kmYiy-GO_hYZt1dCVCrkg.text: Best (vegetarian) pho in Pittsburgh, served with fresh herbs and always piping hot. I've also tried many of the other vegetarian dishes, including General Tso's Tofu, Lo Mein, and fresh spring rolls and they were all delicious!  This place consistently has fresh food and great service.

03J8c2Q0MDG6AHQXoD8f7g.text: If you are vegetarian, this is the best Vietnamese place in town!  The BV-2 has three different types of veggie meat (yes 3!) and even has a veggie version of the fish sauce to pour over it.  Amazing!  This place is out of control good!

rODF2x_Kbz1RQdzcDHlgug.text: My girlfriend and I had an awesome experience here. She got the spicy basil tofu and I got the beef pho. Both were delicious. However, The real reason I'm writing this is because we ordered the veggie spring rolls and a new server accidentally gave ours to another table. No big deal. But the daughter of the owner (I think), came out personally with an order of crispy spring rolls w pork and apologized for the mix up. She assured us that our veggie rolls were on their way, but she wanted to make sure we had something to eat. Who does that? Anyway, holy delicious. I'm so happy they accidentally goofed our order because those pork spring rolls were out of this world. So, in summary, go here. The food is killer, atmosphere is wonderful, and the staff is so nice. Loved it. Thanks, we'll be back!

JLJt5s_aO5ljow29b1G0tQ.text: This Vietnamese place is located on Murray next door to Zaw's.  It is a Vietnamese Bistro that features Vietnamese, Thai, Japanese foods.  The place is really done well in the inside. It used to be an Italian restaurant.  The decor is hip and not over stated. The vibe is relaxed. We started with the summer rolls that were super fresh with shrimp and tofu inside. The chili sauce was tangy and delicious. The rolls were extremely fresh prepared with the finest ingredients. We then ordered the tofu lemongrass. The waitress told us it was her Mother's traditional recipe. I have had this dish where the tofu is sauteed and then the lemongrass is like a sauce that is poured on top. This dish, however, had the tofu marinated in the lemongrass and then cooked with the sauce on it... Sooo amazing! It made the tofu crispy on the outside with the lemongrass flavor just penetrating through each bite! Fantastic. I ordered the pho chicken. The best I have had in Pittsburgh happened today, with the amazing pho I was served. The broth is so rich with flavor, the rice noodles were ala dente and the plate of bean sprouts, fresh herbs, limes, and jalapenos were awesome! There were fresh herbs on the plate along with the Thai basil and cilantro that I didn't recognize. The waitress explained that these were herbs from Vietnam that were similar to cilantro but authentic to exactly how it would be served in her hometown. I was blown away at the flavor these herbs added! Just amazing! I can't wait to go back and take my mother in law, who lived in Hanoi for three years. If you love pho you must try this place Tan lac Vien.

ZIgRNju1_xgG2o3kMsapyQ.text: I am a new transplant to the Pittsburgh area and was really hoping for some good authentic Vietnamese.  The food here was marginal at best.  The cha gio were tough instead of crisp and they didn't give lettuce to wrap them with.  They also served them after the entrees.  They were out of flank steak for pho.  The very worst part was the service.  It was terrible!  The only reason I give them 2 stars is for the limeade.  They actually got that right.  The search will continue for me.  :(

5_IG6jKkde2febIZMh48Dw.text: We had the Pho, Bun, Rice dish.  The appetizer was ok, entrees were ok, meat was undercooked.  Overrated....

WhWGNObADqAvx2oT40XbQg.text: everything we had was delicious - full of flavor and quality. Definitely best Vietnamese I've had in Pittsburgh.

C_peakMs6TrUYCp4Nf69CA.text: Came here about a week after they opened.  They were still training staff, but they were all very eager to please, and were putting in the effort.  The food itself was very good.  We are huge fans of Vietnamese cuisine and tried their grilled pork chops, pho, and a variety of other appetizers.  They had a beef-stew appetizer with baguette, which is one of our favorites when going to Philadelphia, the east-coast mecca for Vietnamese cuisine.  It was not the best, the Pho and other items were very delicious.  Furthermore, its nice to finally have a Vietnamese restaurant in Pittsburgh that has an intimate formal atmosphere.

cI8WxEc3XtZJtkBjHyZMDw.text: One of my new favorite pho places! And they got a good selection of food choices. Its more expensive than other pho places I am use to, but definitely going back there again!

bWQwMgAB-JqucXt4XypgCw.text: I really like this place. It's small and a bit cramped, but you get a very good meal at a reasonable price and it's BYOB.

OtgdcXHnkBV6NgSzogwSjQ.text: food is goid, however, staff friendness is the best in here. i like this place. i was there 3pm during their staff lunch amd i felt bad.  but they were welcome me and u felt same way.  thanks.

CdFIuYr_ngIJUXQu65jSPg.text: Great Vietnamese food! My boyfriend stopped here for a quick lunch. We walked here from a distance, so we were thankful to be seated right away.  We ordered summer rolls, dumplings, and each got a bowl of pho. I ordered the vegan pho and my boyfriend got beef pho.  They actually have a separate vegan menu which is awesome! Sometimes pho can have broth that isn't vegan, but I was assured by the menu that my meal would definitely be vegan.  Of course we got all of the toppings and herbs for our pho as well. Everything was extremely fresh and delicious.  The service was quick and friendly. The restaurant was generally clean, but the floors were a little sticky.  Overall a solid choice for pho.

M1v9mmy6P4Kzf5MszqdSMw.text: i've been to this restaurant a few times before writing this review. the food itself isn't that great. i'd stick to pho because everything else is pretty bad. i've gotten the bun bo hue here and it's basically salted hot water with noodles.   the last time i was here, i got the banh xeo. not only was the texture soft and floppy instead of crispy the way it should be, there was also this layer of white substance in my crepe. i asked my server about it since it looked like uncooked batter and he replied stating it was just egg whites. how interesting, i thought, considering there isn't supposed to be any eggs in the dish in the first place. so that was a no from me.  also, they never have the escargot in stock even though it's on the menu. so, all in all, a very mediocre experience but that's just the reality of looking for authentic viet food in pittsburgh.

VMM_lUJoiWB8toxUGAzQlQ.text: The drop ceiling, back-against-the-diner-behind you ambience is not very inviting.    But... the Bahn mi is enough for bae and me to share happily by itself, though don't miss out on the pan fried dumplings here.  If you're just looking to slurp soup, this place is PHOnomenal!

jo0oTMt04GkiWq71Btfedg.text: Very good pho, and great service! It's a great place to stop in for lunch if you're out shopping in Squirrel Hill. It has a polish that some other pho places in the area lack, so it might make a nice date restaurant as well. I had the chicken pho and my friend had the beef-- we were both very happy with it. We also had the fresh spring rolls, which were delicious. Overall, definitely worth a visit!

fm_pu6eli-tlSKRBVxLnjQ.text: I had no idea this place existed until a friend recommended it for lunch recently. You could walk up and down Murray 10 times without seeing it. The name apparently means "Happy Place", and the menu has a lovely greeting, wishing that this restaurant becomes a happy place for you :)  I really liked that the back of their menu has an entire vegan section! I think Vietnamese food is not one of my favorite cuisines: I tend to find it a little bland, maybe because I stick to vegetable dishes. Nevertheless, the food here was well presented and very fresh tasting  One low point, we were sort of forgotten about after our food was served. This was kind of a good thing, since my friend and I spent a while catching up before seeking someone to get the check, but if we had been in a hurry it would have been a problem

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. VE5

eQkQEhhRG5gCQ-cNGtBM5Q.text: This is the second time that we were at this restaurant.  The first time was years ago but we wanted some good Pho so we came back. We got a table for four because we met my brother in law and his girlfriend.  My wife and I ordered their fresh summer roll with tofu.  She ordered Pho and I ordered Pho with chicken.  Service was good and quick to get our food.  My brother in law's girlfriend ordered one of their Lettuce Wraps.  It was very interesting.  It was kind of a deconstructed lettuce wrap.  It was on a big plate and she had a full platter of things to put on it.  My wife and I said we have to try that next time that we come here.  Our rolls were good but they weren't best that we have had.  We have had better.  My Pho was really good.  It had everything that I love about Pho and it kept me warm and made me full.  I think this is a decent place for Pho and other Vietnamese dishes.  Very good prices and it's BYOB.  One of the best in the burgh I think.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pho Chicken

RILIIgntFBJZLV8Ds48YKg.text: Tan Lac Vien provides convenience and comfort Vietnamese food. They don't have banh mi.. so I highly recommend coming for their noodle dishes both with or without broth! There's plenty of seating both down stairs and upstairs although they typically reserve upstairs for larger parties. The place is casual, good for dates or groups. Their menu has a good amount of options, offering noodle soups (6 or 7 pho options), noodles w/no broth, rice dishes, lettuce wraps, and vegan options.   The pho is tasty and a huge portion. I like the N1; it comes with all types of meat: rare beef, tendon, tripe, flank, and meatball. I recently tried the bun special: lemongrass marinated pork and grilled shrimp w/ vermicelli noodles, salad, and a crispy pork roll. I would order it again. It's flavorful and comes with so much! The food came out pretty quickly too. I look forward to trying other options there such as the banh hoi (vermicelli lettuce wraps)

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bun special (bv1)

V_7Vve52ntAUCWYMdZWi2A.text: They have really tasty Pho and good service. The restaurant itself is clean but not the most extravagant, certainly not somewhere you'd go for a fancy date night or anything. Overall though, prices are decent and the food is delicious! Definitely worth a visit!

hUIyyeWKh4oFNMoTw89Vlg.text: OK, to be honest, I'd give this restaurant a 1 star rating if we were in SoCal (where the largest population of Vietnamese Americans living outside of Vietnam reside). However, because this is Pittsburgh where there are literally only 3 other viable options, Tan Lac Vien would be considered in the middle of the pack for the reasons below.  Pros: - Restaurant is run by Vietnamese-speaking staff - Fresh veggies are fresh (sprouts, basil, jalepenos) - They have chrysanthemum tea  Cons: - Having to literally wait 30 minutes for food because they are so understaffed. I really felt sorry for the one waiter who had to seat guests, take orders, serve the food, deliver the checks, and clean tables. The owners need to enlist more help! - Broth doesn't have the beefy richness that I expect when eating pho - Space feels slightly stuffy  Don't get me wrong, I really love pho and will definitely come back. I just really hope they have more than one waiter next time.

nEeN5sHUBRz981amd0FzwA.text: This is a hidden gem! We got chicken bahn-mi, a noodle soup with chicken and meatballs, and iced coffee. It was all delicious and tasted fresh and warm. The service was quick and friendly. We will definitely be coming back here soon!

bKmJrsW7zqv1NFkkYPXEUw.text: Restaurant is small, service is not perfect but the food is pretty authentic. I was hoping to try the banh mi but they didn't have any that week. I tried the bun bo hue with a spice level 8 and it was really good , the spice level was perfect and the broth was flavorful , although the broth was not that hot so it took time for the meat to cook. Was not disappointed but wasn't overly impressed. Would come back and try more dishes.

D6odkA19Fpqb48v_-AX8vA.text: Most flavorful pho broth I've had yet. Spring rolls were excellent and the noodle bowl with grilled shrimp and pork was a light and flavorful lunch.  The Vietnamese coffee was super strong and absolutely perfect. Highly recommended

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

GVf1BhC9knrsN1fPUyDocQ.text: Extensive vegetarian/vegan menu and incredible food! The vegetarian bahn mi was up there with the best bahn mis I've had. I got their seitan, which was  excellent, but you can also get tofu. We also ordered the bun vegan. It had good flavor and a decent amount of protein and vegetables. We also ordered a limeade which was the stand out menu option! It was just the right amount of tart and a little carbonated which made it kind of spicy. Very refreshing! This is now my go to bahn mi spot and I will be coming back again and again to try out more of their menu!

OOftryR9UAubZhqNJb0kcg.text: They have a vegetarian / vegan friendly menu and the food is fresh and delicious! We ordered the Vietnamese limeade, Bun Vegan and the vegetarian banh mi with seitan and enjoyed them all. Staff was friendly and helpful. Highly recommended!

r3PQxGrDWcYhRjumdDPntQ.text: Yesterday was a cold day ( well ... anything is "cold" when your use to consecutive days of 100+ in California! Haha!) in Pittsburgh , I really wanted some pho! We walked in to Tan Lac Vien at about 2:20pm when they were about to close at 3 pm - oops! We were one of those customers - sorry!   I ordered the vegan pho but I didn't want tofu, I wanted chicken. The Waitress was more than able to accommodate that. My husband also got pho, but with egg noodles. My dad got one of those bowls with no broth and my step mom ordered fried rice.   The fried rice was hella good. I really liked the bean sprouts in it. My dads bowl was good, it had shrimp and I liked the crunchy texture of it. My pho was good, despite the broth which tasted sort of how a dirty sock smells :\ I never tried the egg noddles before , but I really liked them in my husbands pho.  Oh!! We also ordered fried egg rolls and fresh spring rolls. I didn't try the fresh ones which are my favorite but I did love the fried ones.   They didn't have hot chili oil on the tables nor did they bring anything like that out with the order which was kind of a bummer. I did ask the waitress and she brought something similar like that out   Maybe we came at a bad time or maybe their broth just isn't their strong point. Maybe it was Payback for coming in before closing.   I don't visit Pittsburgh often, I may or may not be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. No broth bowl
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Vegan pho minus tofu added chicken

5CcXNtFDThJap7zzDs1iBw.text: This is the best Vietnamese food I've had in Pittsburgh. The pho broth is very tasty. They're meat is excellent as well. As are their spring rolls. Nothing is bad on the menu. Check it out for yourself!

sDDmynrQ7c1XWiMQLA5AzQ.text: This was my second visit to Tan Lac Vien. I had come almost 3 years back and never came back because I didn't like the food. I wasn't on Yelp at that time, so I may have ordered something wrong. What a mistake!   But this time around, I was using the full potential of Yelp reviews. Given the high rating, I decided to give the place another try. For the appetizer, I tried the fried dumplings. For the main course, I got the Bun Vermicelli Honey Chicken. It is a bowl of Vermicelli noodles, topped with some delicious chicken pieces, some leafy veggies, and a dressing. It has a tangy flavor to it, which goes really well.   One star less because I wasn't very thrilled with their service. We were a group of 10, so it may have been hard to wait on us, but towards the end there weren't too many other diners. It took a long time to bring us the check, and then they messed up the billing.   Otherwise, the food was great. And the location is perfect, bang on Murray, where all the fun is. Definitely worth a shot.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

hACGhfbrr3mvgzPV3qwvag.text: Having grown up in Southern California, I consider myself a bit of a pho connoisseur. I would say the broth here is pretty average - there is a satisfactory amount of beefy flavor and the ginger and onion tastes can be appreciated in the broth. However, I think the broth could be a little heavier and less sweet.   I was also displeased with the freshness of the herbs that came with the pho. The sprouts weren't white and the basil leaves had some dark patches.    Nevertheless, they do make good quality pho here and I find that rather impressive considering the relative lack of Vietnamese restaurants in Pittsburgh.

ucZ_y9_Te9K2aHn-5-uWDw.text: Best place to get pho in Pittsburgh! I always ask for extra noodles bc the regular size isn't enough for me. If you're planning on going here on a hot day just keep in mind there's no AC.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pho with extra noodles

GsU2QYJSdR5wRS-CULLcQg.text: Being Vietnamese, I find it hard to be impressed with Vietnamese restaurants, but WOW was I impressed! They feature a large variety of vegetarian/vegan entrees so I was not short on options. The vegan bun was one of the best dishes I've had at a Vietnamese restaurant! Yes, really! The portions were excellent plus, the vegetables tasted fresh and the seitan was delicious. You also get a vegetable spring roll which added a nice crunch to the dish. I loooved the vegan fish sauce (at least I'm hoping it was vegan). It added a little saltiness with some spice and actually tasted like the real deal! I was like a ravenous lion attacking my meal like it was a helpless gazelle (a.k.a. it was not a pretty sight).   Three major downfalls of Tan Lac Vien: service, cleanliness, and price. It took our waitress 10 minutes to "set the table" before we could get seated - and by set the table, I mean put down a napkin. She seemed to be the only waitress in the entire restaurant so service was very slow. When we asked for sauces or refills, she would just completely forget and never return. The restaurant itself is small and cramped, but the real issue is how dirty it is. Nothing gets your appetite going like dust and bugs, am I right? Lastly, although the prices are not completely unreasonable, they are a bit higher than all the other Vietnamese restaurants in the area.   Since the noodles were so good, I didn't have the heart to knock off more than one star for the pitfalls. What can I say, my brain is controlled by my stomach. No question - this is my new go-to Viet restaurant in Pittsburgh!

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bun Chay (vegan)
Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pho Dac Biet

9GBSGY7hq0KO3tW_pVw24Q.text: I'm not an expert in Vietnamese food, but I've experienced the best home-cooked Vietnamese food in Pittsburgh, so I can appreciate it. Tan Lac Vien comes pretty close in quality, and their bun bo hue made my Vietnamese friend happy. They get bonus points for authenticity in their ingredients.

JgjhOhNiqLD66CeI1GlPBA.text: I have been here for many times. But the waitress's attitude is too bad. No greetings, took our sauces without permission,no goodbuy.Nothing!!  She just showed a poker face to us.

m1xA9z-c18HYxg2PJu53pQ.text: The best vietnamese food I've had in Pittsburgh.  I think this place would survive if placed in California or Eden Center (VA).  I had the Bun Dac Biet and it was large and tasty.  What a nice addition to the Squirrel Hill food scene!  I'm looking forward to going back.

0CfhK2nt9BkyUspCLpxH9Q.text: Attention vegetarians: run, don't walk, to Tan Iac Vien. Their vegetarian menu is one of the most extensive I've ever seen at a Vietnamese restaurant. It's the only place I know of, in fact, that serves a vegan pho. All the vegetarian dishes are very well prepared, especially the pho, the com tam, and the bun. Most, if not all, of them come with tofu and other delicious meat substitutes. The waitstaff is super friendly and sweet, too.

wm2tdpY8aywdhkp8elPNwA.text: This place is a Godsend. Just when my search for Vietnamese in Squirrel Hill almost seemed hopeless, there you were. Every thing I have had here is good, and definitely prepared with care and with the right ingredients. The best item is the durian custard dessert. Forget about everything you heard--that durian has the smell of a rotting corpse. It does, but so what, eating it, and eating everything in this place makes you feel grateful that you are alive. Please visit here often, I would love to see this place stay in Pittsburgh for a long time.

VF1lzbJre3Feqv6OLzzX8A.text: It's nice going to a Vietnamese place that's more than just Pho.  Really dug it.  The dishes are really generous and tasty and great for two.  The Com Tam and Banh Xeo are really awesome.

Ex0f89g1vbTOlCwIP8P7oA.text: it has really good pho and rice dishes. best place for a quick lunch. price is a little higher yet acceptable.

BGupBL6iqSMW5eDS2oUZFg.text: Finally got around to trying this place for lunch this weekend and it was a lovely lunch.  The service was wonderful and very friendly.  The dumplings and fresh rolls had nice presentation and consistency..  Really tasty beef pho, they have the right noodles for it.  I had some mushy noodle pho recently and it was the worst.  They clearly have the process down for that.  Love that they provided an abundance of fresh herbs to season, really makes all the difference.  Will be back.  Had a formidable feast for for under 40, so I don't know what the reviews of this placing being overpriced was about.  The small plates were plenty of food to try and completely reasonable.  The grilled pork with the broken rice and fish sauce was succulent to say the least.  I'm sure I'll be back soon.

40de8eMpV1Zfu6wroGrz7A.text: I brought a group of 4 here, so the wide array of dishes made it an attractive option since some in my group had not had Vietnamese food before. The restaurant seats roughly 30-40 and was mostly filled when we came for lunch on a Tuesday afternoon. While they are categorized as a Vietnamese establishment on Yelp, the restaurant menu also offers Chinese, Thai and Japanese - and one can definitely taste that the sauces from the various cuisines are mixed together across dishes, making for less authentic tasting dishes - which are all still very good.  My Vietnamese Bun Thit Nuong (BV1) while very good was a bit reminiscent of take-out Thai (perhaps they used sweet thai chili sauce instead of sambal oelek for spice).  The egg rolls were tasty and crispy; however they were heavy on the pork and had chunky mushroom bits, and were not authentically Vietnamese, though they might have been Vietnamese-inspired. The pho broth on the other hand was very well developed (I could tell they had not taken any shortcuts) - the same goes for the seafood hu tieu (N10) broth.  The food here was good and I am glad to see Vietnamese offerings done this way in Pittsburgh, and would not hesitate to come back.

RE9m-qp_-zY2-F1nxiIFDg.text: The highlight of this place was being able to try Vietnamese food besides the usual pho and bun offered at other locations around the city.  For example, the Vietnamese crepe was an interesting new thing to try and was delicious.  The menu is quite extensive.

oslApNK40rgFEtlngUK7Mg.text: I love a good noodle bowl and  this hit the spot.  I ordered the lemongrass tofu as an app and was a bit disappointed in it. A small piece of tofu rubbed with lemongrass. The star of the meal was the bun dac viet with shrimp and pork. The serving size was just perfect and the shrimp and pork were savory. Don't forget to save room for dessert, the sticky rice with durian sauce was great. Service is very attentive and welcoming.

m8mrOi8kRwDqv5yuHKGIhQ.text: Just had a late lunch here.  I found the Pho Tai to be good, and the "small plate" size (~$7) was substantial enough to make an entire meal of. Despite that, I also tried the fresh summer roll appetizer ($4 / two rolls), which I found to be competently made and nicely presented [sprig of green onion left to protrude from each roll].  I haven't eaten at Tram's Kitchen recently enough to make a solid comparison, but I think this pho was probably on par with Tram's or [very slightly] worse.  The highlight of the meal was the Vietnamese coffee, which is brought to the table in a cup-sized percolator; and is very nicely balanced flavor-wise. Sweet, spicy, and rich without being overly so. I had some hot and some over ice and really enjoyed it both ways.  I, for one, welcome the noodle renaissance that we're going through in Squirell Hill.

RyghN5_HPf3jYjwODTtawQ.text: FINALLY--a great Vietnamese restaurant in Pittsburgh! I have tried all of the Vietnamese places around the area, and so far, this has been the best. Some of the food we ordered included goi du du tom thit (salad), pho dac biet (noodle soup), bun dac biet (vermicelli noodle dish), and com tam bi suon cha (rice dish). These were all delicious and the prices were reasonable! I came with my family, who's also Vietnamese, and they really enjoyed it here. The place is cozy, and the owner is exceptionally friendly and knowledgeable. She also said there's karaoke on the weekend :) Overall, I really recommend coming here and will be coming back again.

b_U5iHxNQ-DweXmVrTmzEw.text: This place is fantastic! We ordered three Vietnamese dishes (a pho, a vermicelli and a noodle dish) and all seemed very authentic. They included flavors I have never tasted before. Authenticity is a rare thing among Asian restaurants in America. The tea (chrysanthemum is recommended) is bottomless and the waiter explained how to eat the tricky Crepes dish, which was very helpful. Service was prompt and warm. Often at Asian restaurants waiters will have trouble understanding English or are difficult to understand so orders get messed up. This was not that case at all here. I will definitely be returning!

j-f63yhEUVPFoRYCJjkkmQ.text: Great food. Pho at lunch is huge, tasty, fresh and plentiful meat & fixin's. Crispy rolls are delicious. Even the green tea was perfect. Delightful server, too.

QMWjXVEpWGDpAJV9csJpGw.text: Went last night with the girlfriend and shared some beef pho and a noodle dish with various meats. The former was pretty good, thanks to some very tasty beef broth; the latter was decent but nothing special. Portions were generous for the price and service was fine. I'd be happy to return to this welcome addition to Murray Avenue.

Xo9IMNX9bz0Z8GlteLRrxw.text: This place is my new favorite spot for pho in pgh.

eZn4CjWhRwJ4McDcU5bjjw.text: I never thought I'd think this about any Vietnamese restaurant, but this place give Tram's Kitchen a run for the money. On the first visit I didn't sample the pho because I had recently had some (at Tram's) but the dishes I did order were terrific, and the pork roll appetizer was especially rocking. Welcome to Squirrel Hill. One star demerit for $2 corkage fee.

mtfMTzbBl8yhfqQmEioBMA.text: Stopped here with a friend for dinner while on a long road trip. Well worth it! I got the pho dac biet (special combination) which is what I pretty much always get at pho restaurants. The broth is clear and flavorful, the noodles are plentiful. We were skeptical at first as the place looks rather trendy, but the soup was on point. The summer rolls, on the other hand, were not so good (no cucumbers, no crunch or spice at all to them, and they did not taste so fresh). So minus one star for that. But I'd make a Pitt-stop again (sorry lame I know) for this pho any day.. it totally hit the spot.

1uN4_C0LqkoTxKp-5QcJpA.text: So delicious!! Never ever fails me :) spring rolls, summer rolls, cheese wontons gotta try them all! Their pho is amazing and always consistent.

85duPJ2Xdt_MqFfbgcvbeA.text: I have been to this restaurant a few times and it always satisfies my craving for pho. It's pretty authentic (based on my previous visits to allegedly genuine Viet places). The proportions are fairly large and the pho broth is very hearty and very filling! The prices are fair too.   As for the menu, I always get pho so I can't testify to any of the other items on the menu. Although, I have tried a bit of their spring rolls, which by the way, are more like Chinese fried egg rolls rather than in the sticky rice paper that you would ordinarily see.  One of the times I came here, I distinctly remember that my server was new and had very inadequate knowledge of the menu and basic etiquette, and it was actually pretty distracting. Otherwise, their service is okay. Nothing spectacular, but they get the job done.  For parking, it's all street parking since the restaurant is right on Murray ave., so just a fair warning if you are supposed to meet someone by a certain time.  Overall, I think it's good. I definitely consider it as my go-to for pho!

ZmYbAhfwffzo3iSoel00aw.text: I have stopped by here twice now for lunch, the first time with my father and most recent with my then fiance for lunch.  The inside of this place is actually quite small and sits maybe about 30 people or so in the main dining area when full.  There aren't too many decorations so to speak of with wooden tables, blank chairs, some up-lighting and then a TV that was showing portions of the menu but got "stuck" while we were there.  This last time that I was there my fiance and I ended up splitting an order of Goi Cuon which is a summer roll with shrimp and pork belly.  Then for my entree I had the con tam bo nuong bi op la which was the broken rice with beef, shredded pork and a fried egg while my fiance went with some shrimp pho.  The summer roll came out first with a sort of sweet and sour sauce and looked really good.  You could actually see the large shrimp through the fairly transparent roll.  It tasted really good too as it was nice and light and paired perfectly with the sweet and spicy sauce.  The only part of it that I didn't really care for was the pork belly but I didn't think that it really affected the flavor at all.  After we finished our appetizer the entrees were delivered.  While my meal was not exactly what I was expecting, it ended up being really good.  The beef was my favorite part of the dish and had some really good flavor.  I also enjoyed breaking the fried egg over the rice to give the rice some richness. My only complaint about our whole time here was the slowness in service.  The place was completely full and it took awhile for us to get both waited on and then for us to pay our bill.  The bottom line for me is that I will be back here again in the future.  While the service was slower than I would have liked, my fiance and I both enjoyed the food that we got.

Cpv_4bKs6YhOHx15GGNI_A.text: Pho broth is delicious, spring rolls were great.   On the expensive side for pho, but location is great. Seating is tight as it's a small restaurant.

N0ZUvWryAJEVybzyTSAqYw.text: Fresh food bursting with flavors that I thought I could only encounter in Asia or San Francisco. I thoroughly enjoyed my pho special, but whenever the server passed my table with a dish for some other table, I had to ask her what it was so that I could remember what to try next time -- it all just looked so delicious! I will be back to try everything on the menu.

YdLBjUtLLehT1fij96ECVQ.text: So i tried this place for lunch one day on a whim.  Being gluten free, i'm not as spontaneous as i would otherwise like to be... however, in the past i have pretty good luck with Viet cuisine.  I explained my dietary restrictions and the hostess was SUPER knowledgeable.  To my utter sadness, the Pho is not gluten free.  However, the BUN Vermicelli dishes and their little spring rolls can be modified.  That first experience i had the BUN GA NUONG ( grilled chicken with rice noodles with fresh herbs, sprouts, cucumber + spring roll)   and since then i've had the BUN THIT NUONG ( grilled pork with rice noodle). Overall this is a great place, limited seating, but very cool.

4QowP-SGZfR7Z5KBMITnXw.text: It took 30 minutes to seat the 2 of us and then another 20 minutes just to get the waiter/waitress attention for water. I wasn't pleased with the weird smell when you walk to the back. Price is ok, but food is not good. I ordered the pho and my noodle was super al dente. I didn't have enough toppings that came with it either. The dumplings we ordered seemed like grocery frozen ones that they just reheated and fried. Super unorganized as well. We immediately asked for the check when they brought us the food and it arrived when we were finishing up.

wKdDOYo3dCDgguxhMoLXPg.text: As good as always.   Have returned and tried more of their fabulous food.  I highly recommend the crepes under the chefs specialty section of their menu.  It is delicious and filling. I also really like their nuoc cham which is out of this world.  Their spring rolls are also very delicious and a great size!   Can't wait to go back!

kf-n_nCCRheD681gEr2zHA.text: I love this place. Easily the best pho in Pittsburg, and solid offerings throughout the menu. Everything I've tried has been great but the pho is so good that my go to is the glorious pho bo vien.

auyH0fvh4ZVQ1nOMSC61hg.text: Pho is my favorite food, and having lived in Pittsburgh for 3 years, Tan Lac Vien is my favorite place to go for pho. Prices aren't amazing, but they aren't exorbitant either. I usually just get the rare beef pho, although I have gotten it with tripe in the past too. I have never gotten anything besides pho at Tan Lac Vien for fear of terrible food regret, but when I went for my 24th birthday, one of my friends got one of the broken rice dishes and liked it a lot. I have also tried a couple of their spring rolls, and they are good too, although lacking the peanut sauce I'm used to from pho places in NJ and NY.   My roommate also likes to get the cheese wontons, but this is the point in the review where I have to mention that service at Tan Lac Vien seems to have gone downhill a bit in the past year or so. My roommate has complained about being told differing things about the cheese wontons either no longer being on the menu or temporarily being unavailable (as of now you can still get it), and a few times she ordered it and they didn't say anything, but then she had to wait exorbitant amounts of time for her takeout order. I've also noticed some changes when dining in. When I went before, the owner, a super friendly young woman, would often come and talk to me. She seemed eager to talk about the dishes on the menu and tell me about which ones were more traditional, and she was ultra accommodating in letting me try different sauces for the spring rolls. I haven't seen her in a while, and service at Tan Lac Vien seems to have gotten worse in recent times. The last time I went there, the server was very...brusque. No smiles, a very blunt/curt response to my question about whether they had bubble tea (it was on the menu but they don't have it). I didn't mind much, as she was prompt about refilling water and the food came out fast, but just a note.   TLDR: Best pho in Pittsburgh. Okay prices. Service has been better in the past but still gets the job done.

FMQ7g1c-OFP2NMyU2d5Wtw.text: Very good pho! I've been traveling a lot for work and made it my mission to have pho everywhere I go, so I have a few to compare it to and it's in the top.  Stay away from the dumplings as they are obviously previously frozen. Ours came cold in the middle.  We also split the chef's special crapes, which were fresh, unusual, but very tasty! They were surprisingly busy for a Monday, but we got seated quickly and the food did not take a long time at all. This place is BYOB. Wish would have known ahead of time.  Will definitely be back!!!

2l8454XRGH-jDxeRiIUyuw.text: This restaurant is fantastic.  My husband and I came here for Valentines Day.  The staff was very informative and welcoming.  I got the Pad Thai and it was the best Pad Thai I have ever had. I have had it in a few places in the city but this was so delicious. My husband ordered the chow fun and that was also very tasty.   We also ordered cheese wontons as an appetizer and you could tell they were fresh made there. Very tasty.  I would recommend eating here for any kind of Asian cuisine you're craving since their menu includes a lot of options.

I2Gp86kzh4ujxugZLn_XXA.text: The vegetable Pho was excellent!!!! All fresh herbs and veggies...I think it's a little overpriced for just vegetables, and broth. $12.00 for a bowl.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

wNfBB3ZDndWc25EfiQUHUA.text: This place just keeps getting better. The 'broken rice' dishes with grilled marinated meat are great. I have not seen this dish at any other Vietnamese restaurant, and it is delicious. Meats are consistently cooked perfectly. Great combination of rich fish sauce flavors with crisp veggies, and traditional sides of basil, mint and sprouts. Other standouts: Beef salad which is spicy with strong citrus flavors; Bahn Hoi--rice noodle wraps which you assemble yourself--these are really great.

irw3ZUIL-6-H-B4QJuueIQ.text: I'm a fan! I came here for lunch and had the shrimp and pork belly summer roll and the grilled chicken bun. Both were good. The service is attentive and helpful and fast! I will be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. What&#39;s left of my grilled chicken bun. Yum!

msY-0VXrccLr5ZtgYL2Pag.text: I've been eating at Tan Lac Vien for quite some time now and I can say that I have never left disappointed.  The meals are delicious, flavorful, varied, unique, well-portioned fairly-priced, and have never left me questioning whether or not what I am eating is the meat it was advertised to be.  The ingredients are quality.  Now, despite how many times I've been here, I've never felt tempted to try the General Tso's. Why would I get the stereotypical American dish when there is so much more to choose from?  Well, one night, my dad, a friend and I came here and one of the waitresses recommended that the friend try the general tso's tofu.  My.God.  It is hands down the most delicious General Tso's I have ever tried! Fast forward to today, and I finally gave in.  I ordered the General Tso's with Chicken and Brocolli.. It was amazing!  The chicken was actually chicken, thick, cubed cuts of, if I could italicize, lightly breaded chicken breast chunks tossed in a homemade sauce that has a wonderful smoky flavor to it from what I imagine to be the chili peppers in it.  Needless to say, this was magnitudes of order better than any General Tso's I've had anywhere-- you know, that crap that is like an inch thick of breading with chicken by-products.  Anyway, to my list of favorites:   Com Tom Ga: Broken rice, chicken, veggies, an egg, and fish sauce Bun Ga: a noodle dish various seafood dishes  I can now add the General Tso's.  Also, the entire staff is extremely friendly and knowledgeable about the menu. Don't be afraid to go in and ask them for suggestions-- they are good a making them, and moreover, don't be afraid of asking how to eat certain things, because sometimes it can be confusing, and yes, there are intended ways of eating some of the dishes.

mwCL83e69_0OkZcZqYP7rQ.text: Very good Pho, only reason for 4 stars is because service can be slightly slow during a lunch break.

ykuPw6M6vXmn2XvkjwbXVA.text: I'm obsessed with pho right now and there chicken pho is on point delicious.  There seems to be the same guy working the whole place so at times it may take awhile to be seated and get the food. I was unaware that they close at a certain time during the week that transitions from lunch to dinner and felt bad because i was the only person in there but other than that it's a cool little ethnic place visit!

IEsrYXzHWV4HIeDeEOHlug.text: Above all this restaurant suffers from a seeming lack of experience.  I can overlook mediocre service if the food is decent to good (unfortunately the food was fair at best).  It took a very long time to get our tea and appetizers.  And when the main dishes finally arrived, the waitstaff was very confused as to which dishes were what and in fact, some of them were incorrect.    Additionally, the timing was off (i.e. main dishes served at different times, and appetizers served with mains).  Having enjoyed several quality Vietnamese meals, the fact that the best dish on the table was a Chinese dish is problematic.  All of the main dishes in my party lacked flavor.  Finally, the establishment had an unappetizing odor, which detracted from our dining experience.  Our waitress did not even thank us at the end of the night, which really should just go without saying.

7R-t-Z8WsK1T87jvXCK6Eg.text: My favorite Vietnamese food place in Pittsburgh so far. They have good varieties of entrees and app. We ordered fresh spring rolls, sugar cane shrimp wrap, thick noodle in spicy lemongrass soup and vermicelli wrap and we love them all. Will definitely be back to try other dishes!

hVMWJ4FJhcnIKrl3oa-ksg.text: Their Pho was delish and they have pretty good service. They give you good portion sizes. Def worth a visit!

lO7-LSo6LO8SqTFR1Gj0pg.text: I don't do reviews often, but I'd like to write some down for this place.   The Pho, or the noodles, are not authentic at all. I've tried Pho across the United States and in Asia. This is just at the very bottom of everything I tasted.   The service, which I saw quite a few reviews mentioned, is terrible. There were two waitress when we were eating there. One of them was pretty good and nice. The other one, is really rude! I asked for a small plate for sauce dipping. She stared at me and said very loudly: "What?! You have one plate right there!" I'm new to the city and I'm not sure how this restaurant is still open with this type of service. Later on, I heard another table appeared to be asking for something, and this waitress literally responded with: "For what?!" I was very shocked.   The iced water we asked for has definitely no ice and has room temperature.   I will not visit this place again.

feA-y035Dy6yq7HJHEZ9Zg.text: My review might be a bit biased because I leave real close and love pho, but the food is pretty solid even if the service is not all that great - they don't seem to have a lot of staff on call and once I had to wait an hour for my meal. While I find the pho to be slightly saltier and greasier than average, it isn't bad.

gfsRDYXypZW2iDSwe9n1qQ.text: Though I am Chinese, my parents were both born and raised in Vietnam, and only left because of the war. At home, I ate Vietnamese way more than Chinese food, and grew up in Boston, where the Vietnamese population is huge, and the bar for food is high. Moving to Pittsburgh, one of my first missions was to make sure I could get a good bowl of pho (fyi: "pho" sounds like "fuh," not like "foe")--my grandmother always taught me that you can judge the caliber of a Vietnamese place by the quality of their pho broth.   The pho broth here was clear and sweet, in that rich savory way that bone broth that has been stewed for hours and hours should be, not the salty hit that you get with boullion/msg-based soups. The noodles were silky and the right amount of thickness. I thoroughly enjoyed it.  My mom, who was with me at the time, had a bowl of their bun bo hue (a little spicy, a lot delicious, for those of you out there who are a little more adventurous when it comes to Asian food), and gave it 4/5 stars when I asked her about flavor and authenticity. It came with the authentic herb pairing on the side (each different Vietnamese noodle soup has a specific combination of herbs that it should come with--pho herbs are different from bun bo hue herbs. Use them by shredding them into your soup while its still hot for the most authentic flavor). My mom really liked that they serve their soups piping hot because she hates lukewarm noodle soup more than anything else. Now that this place has passed my pho test, I'll definitely be coming back here for bun bo hue and other noodle soups in the future!  Definitely recommend.   (p.s. It's not a super fancy or large place, but I don't really trust any Vietnamese place that puts on airs anyway.)

tqfm_KHrydpY7PgRakoVAA.text: Um, pass.  One taste of this place's pho and bun dish and I knew it was just missing something.  The food is definitely subpar to Vietnam Pho and the prices are higher.  It's missing the feeling of a traditional Vietnamese restaurant.  Maybe because they try to serve Chinese food too.  Maybe because I feel crammed next to other diners in a small back room with 10 other tables.  Maybe because the dishes were skimpy on the meat.    One dinner here including 1 bun, 1 pho, 1 spring roll, 1 sprite, tax, and tip got us almost up to 40 dollars!  It does complete the nice array of Asian food restaurants in Squirrel Hill and it may be good for a Vietnamese food newbie because the waiters will explain what everything is.  But it just didn't do it for me and I won't be back anytime soon.

n__y4WRqH6jyQQEcH4nAyA.text: Drive all the way in to Squirrel Hill to get Pho only to find the door locked and a note on the door that said closed 3pm-5pm?!? Would be nice for you to advertise this in your website, because the last time I checked, it said open from 11am-10pm. Really annoying!

xt8xj542x1YRrMy_czi1Ng.text: I had the beef pho, lemongrass tofu, and veg spring rolls. All equally tastey. I am impressed that they have items on their menu you will not find elsewhere in pgh.  I ordered to go and my wait was about 20 min more than I was told. But small price to pay. For awesome eats.

CyZJA6nFoJakTPlR1Nv8tQ.text: This is regarding a visit on 5/16. We waited 55 minutes for our pho. Fifty- five minutes. I don't care how busy the restaurant is that is unacceptable. I know that the preparation for pho requires little to no cooking as everything is already pre-made. Literally unacceptable.   Not beyond the service, the food is subpar and overpriced. 10-13$ for pho is way too much. I don't care how good that is.

_yeguzH_kZ1zRN0giBdlLA.text: I was convinced by my friend to come here with him and I would say that it was a good experience.   The pad thai was not the best I had ever had but it wasn't bad and the portion was rather big for one person.  The pad thai had a really good ratio of basil to noodle though.  However, it wasn't as peanut-y as I would have liked...  The service was nice and the food came out pretty fast.  The place itself was rather cool, it was very modern looking without looking tacky.

H637xzoMua8kY6anit_Hqg.text: I love noodles and meat, so naturally I love pho. I usually just get a standard pho tai here. They are very accommodating with my requests to not have any veggies or extras in there, and happily brought out peanuts for my dish when I asked. The seating here is nice and comfortable, the place is small but has a good atmosphere. The serving staff is nice and prompt with requests. If you're looking for decent pho, you can't go wrong here.

gTvZirlck53UpBxeXEh5Sg.text: I want to give this place a 3.5, but I rounded down because although the food is fantastic, the service was sub-par and the main dining area is so tiny you can't help but hear the conversations going on at all the surrounding tables. The one time I ate in, the wait staff mistakenly took our food to a different table before picking it back up and bringing it to us. If it had sat much longer with the other guests, I would have asked for the food to be remade.  The food itself has been nothing but delicious- I've had veggie egg rolls, veggie spring rolls, and General Tso's chicken. They've all been served fresh and at the proper temperature (sometimes an issue at other Asian restaurants in the area). The portions of the entrees are huge and definitely can be eaten for 2 full meals.  Overall, though, I'd recommend getting takeout from here instead of eating in the restaurant.

_-oilbNyumB0WryA0hYdxw.text: "A happy new place" is what the name of this incredible restaurant translates to. Finally, was able to make it in to see Thy and Steve Ngo's recent creation.  The dining experience was incredible.  The menu was extensive, and the options, if you're not sure what to order, are placed on a flat screen with beautiful photos attached to see what you're ordering before it even comes out! The quality was unprecedented for the Pittsburgh area.  I'm very well traveled, and my Pho experiences in NYC and Boston have been sub par to the quality and taste here.  And in Pittsburgh?!?! truly a gem.  Sorry I waited so long to come in and have a taste.  Friendly staff and once again Steve and Thy have done it again, so fortunate to have a great authentic, Vietnamese option in the Burgh!

NBn-dbFkaQH-ZoAl0v8lYw.text: Very happy with my first visit! I ordered the chicken Pho, and was completely satisfied. The broth was flavorful, and the portion large. I do think they charge a bit more than other places around town, but for me location and quality are completely worth it. I will be back, definitely. I personally think it's the best pho in town. My dining companion ordered the bun vermicelli and was quite happy also.

C-Eypqh7ryDUWdGCP-WkSw.text: Popped in to here for lunch at 1 after a friend had recommended this place for Vietnamese. I was greeted when I entered and was sat immediately in the main eating area. I ordered the Dac Biet ($13) with a Diet coke ($1.50) and boy did this meal hit the spot. The pork was just a tad over done but had such a great grill taste, the shrimp and egg roll were perfect and were accompanied by lots of noodles and veggies along with the special sauce. The hostess/waitress checked in on me and provided great service including a smooth and swift check out via credit card. The restaurant was about a third full the entire time I was there though note the main area has about seven tables and there are two in the front. I'll have to return and try the pho next time!

bCxV8XgM4G6Kg883B1O3LQ.text: Bad server , rude for changing the beef to ham which could be possibly down at any other restaurant, long wait time only one server for everything !!!  No water served ! Ask to wait  when We ask for a cup of water .

Z2_j-yRSC_KjcLdsIK1V2g.text: It took too long to get my pho even for lunch.  The pho was okay, nothing special. I like Pho Minh better. My friend ordered red curry and he wasn't impressed either.  I may come back to try other dishes, especially since they offer small plates.

photos.caption: Photo of Tan Lac Vien - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pho

8Du4vNV54zDtPYbG8MvijA.text: Been here a few times and tried several dishes. My favorite use to be the pho, but feel the quality food has changed, the service is mediocre, and will be finding a new pho place to go.

x8xjp4XpCEd_MSRcYwgjUw.text: I went with a group of 5 and the servers were really nice and helpful. I appreciated the fact that they didn't give us any trouble when we wanted to split the check. They were also able to recommend some dishes when we asked. Three people got pho and said it was good but not anything mind-blowing. One person got fried rice and said it was ok. I got the vermicelli noodles (not in soup) with grilled shrimp, pork, and egg roll. It was also ok. (I didn't particularly like the basil flavor that was in the dish and the pork was a bit too fatty.) Everyone agreed they would give this place 3 1/2 stars, but Yelp doesn't do that.  To be honest, I was shocked at how expensive the dishes were. My dish was $13. It was a large bowl, but usually Vietnamese food isn't that pricey. The restaurant wasn't a particularly classy restaurant (at the time that I went, they had two buckets in the entryway catching what I suppose is water dripping from the ceiling). The menus were laminated and the napkins were just paper napkins. As someone coming from NYC and used to some pricey meals, I think the cost of a meal here is a bit high for the food that they're serving and the ambiance that they present. Hope that doesn't sound snobby, but I don't think it's worth going back.

3eP7Fq7AwVNsYp-yCyTd1Q.text: I am so glad I finally tried this little Vietnemese restaurant in my neighborhood.  I loved the pho, the bun, and the summer rolls.  They also had a secret banh mi sandwich menu when I was last there though I think they added it to their main menu now.  The banh mi was also excellent and a great lunch option.  I went twice over a two month period and the girl recognized me and remembered what I ordered even though weeks had passed!  She was quite friendly and made it a welcoming experience.  The food is some of the best vietnemese I've had in Pittsburgh.

kzepRFa8z-_LRr93PJWrXw.text: This was the first time I ever tried vietnamese food and the food was amazing. I told the lady attending to me that we were first timers and she was patient with us and explained to us how a dish would be served. We tried their salad rolls with shrimp, salad and cheese wontons. The highlight of the meal were the salad rolls which came with fresh herbs and you get to prepare it urself using a rice paper which was really very interesting.  The serving size is also huge so it's great value for money.  the only problem with the restaurant is it's not really fancy and indeed the furniture looks even cheaper to sit on. I am a student and don't mind the ambience at all until my taste buds are satisfied. Would definitely recommend this to anyone.

H3iIa3n0a6B3BRkPV-A08Q.text: I came here mid afternoon for a late lunch with a friend today, and enjoyed a delicious vegetarian pho and some spring rolls.   All of the ingredients were superb and fresh, and the vegetable broth was quite deliciously flavored. It really hit the spot on such a cold day.  Interior decor was pleasant, a bit modern but not tacky. The server we had was very helpful in selections and was very friendly. I'll definitely come back to try more of their menu items.
